Acquisition”). This offering circular contains the audited consolidated financial statements of G4S and its subsidiaries
as of and for each of the years ended December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2019. This financial information has been
prepared in accordance with the international accounting standards in conformity with the requirements of the UK
Companies Act 2006 and with international financial reporting standards adopted pursuant to Regulation (EC) No
1606/2002 as it applies in the European Union (“IFRS”), and are presented in pound sterling, and therefore is not
readily comparable to the audited financial statements of Allied Universal Holdco LLC, which have been prepared in
accordance with GAAP and have been presented in US dollars.

**NON-GAAP AND NON-IFRS FINANCIAL MEASURES**

In addition to the financial information presented in this offering circular prepared in accordance with GAAP
or IFRS, as applicable, this offering circular contains “non-GAAP financial measures” and “non-IFRS financial
measures,” that is, financial measures that either exclude or include amounts that are not excluded or included in the
most directly comparable measures calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP or IFRS, as applicable. We
present Allied Adjusted EBITDA, G4S Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma
Combined Adjusted Revenue as supplemental measures of our performance that are not required by or presented in
accordance with GAAP or IFRS, as applicable. We define Allied Adjusted EBITDA as net income (loss) before
interest expense, net, income tax (benefit) expense and depreciation and amortization, as further adjusted to exclude
certain non-cash items and certain cash expenses management considers non-recurring, unusual or otherwise not
indicative of our ongoing operating performance and to reflect the full expected effect of cost reduction and profitenhancing initiatives, acquisitions, disposals and related cost and revenue synergies. Specific adjustments for the fiscal
years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 include adjustments for transaction, integration and restructuring costs,
sponsor and director fees, non-cash equity-based compensation, legal settlements and related fees, certain adjustments
related to the implementation of Allied Universal’s accounting standards, loss on disposal of property and equipment,
loss on early extinguishment of debt, (gain) loss on disposal of businesses, and miscellaneous other non-recurring
adjustments, as further adjusted to give effect to start-up costs and lease costs, profit-improvement initiatives,
unrealized synergies from certain acquired businesses, management’s estimates of EBITDA from certain acquired
businesses generated prior to their acquisition date, management’s estimates of EBITDA from certain businesses
acquired in 2021, profits related to disposed businesses, and other non-recurring adjustments, which are described in
the section entitled “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated and Pro Forma Combined Financial Information.”
We define G4S Adjusted EBITDA as profit / (loss) before interest expense, net, income tax (benefit) expense and
depreciation and amortization, as further adjusted to exclude certain non-cash items and certain cash expenses
management considers non-recurring, unusual or otherwise not indicative of our ongoing operating performance.
Specific adjustments for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 include adjustments for transaction and
integration costs, director fees, non-cash equity-based compensation, legal settlements and related fees, loss (gain) on
disposal of property and equipment, loss (gain) on contingent consideration, certain IFRS adjustments, start-up costs,
lease costs, management’s estimates of EBITDA related to disposed businesses, constant currency exchange rate
adjustments and other non-recurring adjustments described in the section entitled “Summary—Summary Historical
Consolidated Financial Information of G4S.” Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA has been determined based on
the combined statements of operations of Allied Universal and G4S for the year ended December 31, 2020 as adjusted
as described under “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information.” and as further adjusted to
reflect certain non-recurring adjustments and unrealized synergies in connection with the Financing Transactions and


-----

G4S Acquisition as described under “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated and Pro Forma Combined
Financial Information.” We define Pro Forma Combined Adjusted Revenue as Allied Universal’s historical revenue,
as adjusted to give effect to businesses acquired during 2020 and 2021 by Allied Universal, plus G4S’s historical
revenue, as adjusted to give effect to revenue from businesses held for sale by G4S, onerous contracts, revenue from
businesses disposed of by G4S during 2020 and 2021 and constant currency exchange rate adjustments. You are
encouraged to evaluate these adjustments and the reasons we consider them appropriate for supplemental analysis. In
evaluating these non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures, you should be aware that in the future we may incur expenses
that are the same as or similar to some of the adjustments in this presentation. Our presentation of these non-GAAP
and non-IFRS measures should not be construed as an inference that our future results will be unaffected by unusual
or non-recurring item.

We present these non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures because we believe they assist management and
investors when analyzing our performance by providing meaningful information that facilitates the comparability of
underlying business results from period to period. We recognize these measures are not measurements of financial
performance under GAAP and IFRS and there are limitations associated with the use of non-GAAP and non-IFRS
financial measures. Some of these limitations are:

    - other companies may use different methods to calculate similar non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures, and
the measures we present may not be directly comparable with the measures presented by these other
companies as a result;

    - such measures do not reflect our cash expenditures, or future requirements for capital expenditures or
contractual commitments;

    - such measures do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

    - such measures do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary to
service interest payments, on our debts; although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges,
the assets being depreciated and amortized will often have to be replaced in the future, and these
measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements;

    - non-cash compensation is and will remain a key element of our overall long-term incentive compensation
package, although we exclude it as an expense when evaluating our ongoing operating performance for
a particular period;

    - such measures do not reflect the impact of certain cash charges resulting from matters we consider not
to be indicative of our ongoing operations; and

    - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their
usefulness as comparative measures.

Allied Adjusted EBITDA, G4S Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA are adjusted
to reflect certain acquisitions and certain unrealized acquisition synergies anticipated to be achieved in connection
therewith. We present these adjustments as they will be permitted as adjustments to “EBITDA” under the indentures
that will govern the notes offered hereby, although the non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures included herein may be
defined differently than the corresponding terms under such indentures, and to enable investors to understand the
covenants that will apply to us, and not as a projection of future results. We will be required to make cash expenditures
to achieve such cost savings, and these cash costs are not reflected in Allied Adjusted EBITDA, G4S Adjusted
EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA. In addition, we will not fully realize such cost savings within
12 months of the completion of this notes offering, and may not do so at all. Accordingly, you should not view our
presentation of this adjustment as a projection that we will achieve these acquisition synergies. Our ability to realize
these acquisition synergies is subject to significant uncertainties and you should not place undue reliance on the
adjustments in evaluating our anticipated results. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industries—
We may not realize the expected benefits, revenue or cost synergies related to recently completed or future
acquisitions” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the G4S Acquisition—We may fail to realize all of the anticipated


-----

benefits of the G4S Acquisition or those benefits may take longer to realize than expected. We may also encounter
significant difficulties in integrating the G4S business.”

Because of these limitations, non-GAAP and non-IFRS financial measures should not be considered in
isolation or as substitutes for, or as superior to, the presentation of results determined in accordance with GAAP and
IFRS, as applicable. For a reconciliation of Allied Adjusted EBITDA, G4S Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma
Combined Adjusted EBITDA to the most directly comparable GAAP and/or IFRS financial measures, see
“Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated and Pro Forma Combined Financial Information” and “Summary—
Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information of G4S.”

**Our Company**

**Business Overview**

Allied Universal is North America’s leading security and facility services provider. With over 250,000
security professionals and offices located throughout the United States as well as internationally (Canada, Mexico,
and the United Kingdom), Allied Universal serves approximately 14,800 clients and is responsible for protecting more
than 50,000 client sites covering multiple specialty sectors such as higher education, healthcare, retail, commercial
real estate, government, and corporate campuses, including a significant portion of the Fortune 500 companies. Allied
Universal’s services span manned guarding, innovative technology systems, risk and consulting, janitorial and staffing
services, integration services, and digital solutions and remote monitoring.

We are responsible for providing “best-in-class” security services that allow clients to completely outsource
the recruiting, screening, hiring, training, uniforming, scheduling and supervision of security officers. Our security
officers work on-location at customer sites and are responsible for observing, detecting, deterring and reporting and
responding to perceived, potential or actual security threats. We also provide specialized security services such as
vehicle patrol, visitor management, K-9 security services, top security facility cleared security professionals, and joint
security programs. We have an operational presence in all 50 US states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico and
have a growing presence in Canada, Latin America, and the United Kingdom.

In addition to providing manned guarding services, we provide comprehensive technology solutions to our
customers, including video surveillance, closed circuit television (“CCTV”) picture capture and monitoring, robot
patrolling, GPS-based patrol and reporting, management of access control points and centralized security operations.
We also offer systems integration services to design, install and service fully integrated technology-based monitoring
systems, along with digital solutions and remote monitoring through our Monitoring and Response Center (“MaRC”).
We are able to leverage our large manned guarding customer base and service platform to cross-sell these additional
system integration services. Finally, we offer a range of ancillary services, including temporary and permanent
staffing, event staffing and security, janitorial services, and consulting and investigation solutions.

Allied Universal was formed in August 2016 through the combination of AlliedBarton Security Services
(“AlliedBarton”) and Universal Services of America (“Universal”), which brought together two of the leading
providers in the security services industry. AlliedBarton, founded in 1957, and Universal, founded in 1965, were
leaders in the industry in customer service, organic growth, customer and employee retention, accretive mergers and
acquisitions (“M&A”), and had a highly complementary and diverse set of blue chip customers. The combined
company became the largest provider of security officer services in North America and has continued to grow since,
both organically and through M&A. In the fourth quarter of 2018, Allied Universal acquired U.S. Security Associates
Holdings, Inc., a leading North American provider of security solutions, including manned security, consulting,
investigations, and disaster and emergency response services. Since 2007, the company has successfully executed 72
acquisitions, including small and large tuck-ins. In the fourth quarter of 2019, Allied announced the acquisition of


-----

SOS Security, LLC (“SOS Security”) which brought a complementary approach and further scale to Allied Universal.
As of 2020, Allied Universal has an estimated 31% share of the highly fragmented outsourced manned guarding
security services market in the United States, with a track record of growth driven both organically and through
acquisitions.

For the year ended December 31, 2020, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, we had
Pro Forma Combined Adjusted Revenues of $18,357.1 million and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA of
$1,955.9 million, respectively. See “—Summary Historical Consolidated and Pro Forma Combined Financial
Information” for a reconciliation of Pro Forma Combined Adjusted Revenues and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted
EBITDA to revenues and net income (loss), the most directly comparable GAAP and/or IFRS measures.

**G4S Acquisition**

On December 8, 2020, the governing boards of Allied Universal and of G4S announced that they had reached
agreement on the terms of a recommended cash offer, to be made by Atlas UK Bidco Limited (“Allied Bidco”), a
newly incorporated entity that is indirectly controlled by Allied Universal, to acquire the entire issued and to be issued
share capital of G4S, with G4S’ directors recommending Allied Universal’s offer of 245 pence per share, representing
a purchase price of approximately £3.8 billion and total enterprise value of approximately £5.4 billion (the “G4S
Offer”). On March 16, 2021, we announced the offer becoming unconditional as to acceptances, having received valid
acceptances representing approximately 79% of total G4S shares. On April 6, 2021, the G4S Offer became wholly
unconditional, and we completed the G4S Acquisition.

**G4S Overview**

G4S is a leading global security company, specializing in the provision of security services and solutions to
customers around the world. G4S’s roots can be traced back approximately 120 years ago to 1901, when the guarding
company Kjøbenhavn Frederiksberg Nattevagt was established in Denmark. Since then, G4S has expanded both
organically and through acquisitions, culminating in the merger of Securicor and Group 4 Falck to create G4S in 2004.
G4S is active in 90 countries across the globe, has more than 490,000 security professionals, and purchases goods and
services from approximately 40,000 suppliers. G4S has security integration capabilities in more than 40 key markets
and more than 13,000 monitored end points with key markets across the Americas, Africa, Asia and EMEA. Key
services include system design, integration & maintenance, manned & mobile guarding, monitoring & response,
consultancy & risk management, analytics, equipment and software. G4S provides its services to a broad range of
customers across various types of sites, including Fortune 500 companies, construction sites and manufacturing
facilities, hospital campuses and healthcare facilities, oil, gas, energy and other regulated facilities, financial
institutions and banking centers, college and university campuses, courthouses and government buildings, law
enforcement support including detainee processing and transport, and gated and residential communities.

Through its Secure Solutions segment, G4S is a global market leader in security, providing both traditional
manned-guarding and technology-enabled security solutions in addition to consultancy services and analytics to its
customers. G4S uses its expertise, service delivery and integration alongside its geographic scale to differentiate the
business to customers, drive outsourcing and enhance the value of traditional security services through greater use of
technology. G4S officers are tailored for the specific need of each client, including the following: custom protection
officers who meet stringent experience and training requirements and are prepared to step into high profile locations;
upscale security officers who perform security patrols of designated areas on foot or in a vehicle; lobby ambassadors
who present a professional and courteous appearance while also possessing customer service skills and focus and bank
protection officers who provide visible deterrence of criminal activity at entrances of financial institutions and banking
centers. Currently, technology-enabled security services represent approximately 45% of Secure Solutions revenue.
G4S is focused on pivoting from manned guarding to “predictive” security services with consulting, technology,
people and data analytics to continue margin expansion going forward.

G4S’ Cash Solutions segment is comprised of the Retail Technology Solutions and Conventional Cash
divisions. On February 26, 2020, G4S announced it agreed to sell the majority of its Conventional Cash businesses to
Brink’s for cash consideration of £666 million, allowing it to focus on the growth of its core integrated security
solutions business and further develop the rapidly growing Retail Technology Solutions business. Retail Technology
Solutions provides unique, value-add cash management solutions to clients and goes to market through the brands


-----

Retail Cash Solutions, CASH360, Desposita, G4SPay, and South Africa-Deposits. G4S technologies offer a breadth
of solutions to clients including automated cash management and reconciliation and unique forecasting tools for retail
cash operations. Conventional Cash services include armored cash transportation, typically facilitated between cash
centers and customer outlets, as well as counterfeit detection, cash redistribution to banks and ATMs, ATM
management, including cash forecasting, replenishment, reconciliation and maintenance, counting and secure
international transportation of cash and valuables including, but not limited to, currency, gems and precious metals.

**Strategic Rationale**

**Enhances the combined company’s geographic coverage and capabilities to serve customers, especially in the**
**core North America market, which represents approximately 70% of pro forma combined revenues**

We believe the G4S acquisition is a strategically and financially compelling transaction that will expand our
geographic footprint, enhance our scale, diversify our products and services offering, increase market position and
provide new growth channels in untapped regions and end-markets. The acquisition of G4S provides Allied Universal
with a unique opportunity to acquire a well-established integrated security services company with a globally
recognized security services brand, and platform to increase the combined company’s top line sales and profitability.
Allied Universal and G4S are two of the top five global companies in the highly fragmented security services industry
based on revenue. Together, we will be a global leading company in the security services.

The transaction enhances the combined company’s geographic coverage and capabilities to serve customers,
especially in the core North America market, which represents approximately 70% of pro forma combined revenues.
Allied Universal has a strong footprint in North America with a presence in all 50 states, and the merger with G4S
creates unparalleled scale and increases density, with footprint overlap allowing the combined company to take a bestof approach to servicing clients in the various regions. Based on revenue generation, we rank number one in Manned
Guarding and Retail Technology solutions and number three in Security Technology in North America. We provide
a comprehensive, diverse product offering with value-added services and world-class quality to our end-customers.
We believe our increased scale in multiple regions and the breadth of our services will make our services more
attractive to our customers. Both Allied Universal and G4S provide diversified solutions in addition to traditional
manned guarding services. The Allied Universal and G4S transaction creates a fully integrated security business with
the ability to address customers’ evolving security needs in an increasingly evolving and fast-changing world with
increased demand.

**Increases diversification across end-markets, customers and geographies**

While Allied Universal has historically focused more on the North American region, the acquisition of G4S
enables Allied Universal to significantly increase its global footprint and diversify its base to operating in over 90
countries. The combination with G4S establishes Allied Universal as a global security services leader with unmatched
scale and expertise in providing quality security services across a range of geographies. The combination of Allied
Universal’s and G4S’s solutions and significant manned-guarding businesses will create a global one-stop-shop for
customers and a business ideally positioned to lead the industry shift from traditional security officer and patrol
services towards services that integrate technology solutions with manned security services. See “—Industry
Overview—Security Services Technology.” Allied Universal’s decades of experience in risk advisory and consulting,
investigations, executive protection and emergency response will complement G4S’s corporate risk services to provide
end-to-end security solutions. With appropriate support, capital and assistance from Allied Universal, G4S would be
able to concentrate on addressing the ongoing industry shift towards electronic and technology-based services.

**Strengthens platform with blue chip customer base**

The combination of Allied Universal and G4S will create a world-leading integrated security business
providing services to an extensive portfolio of blue-chip clients across the public and private sectors. We sell to a
diversified customer base and end-markets in various verticals, including commercial real estate, retail and malls,
government, healthcare, tech and media, manufacturing and industrial, financial institution, chemical and
petrochemical, and aerospace and defense. We are the trusted provider to premium accounts for clients with greater
than $5 million annual revenue across multiple regions and a central point of contact for purchasing security services.
Our leading global scale helps promote trust and confidence among our sophisticated customers and serves as a


-----

significant differentiator versus regional competitors. The combination expands Allied Universal’s base of long
tenured blue chip customers globally and uniquely positions the combined company to serve customers seeking
integrated security solutions providers of scale. Allied Universal has had annual revenue retention of over 90% for the
past 5 years and has minimal customer concentration with top five customers representing less than 5% of revenues.
Doing business and negotiating long-term contracts through a centralized procurement division drives strong valueadded partnerships underpinned by highly sticky relationships, which increase the switching costs for our customers.

**Acquisition adds density and expertise to North America technology business**

The combined group will increase Allied Universal’s reach and depth of services, enhancing our leadership
position and allowing us to expand internationally on current domestic accounts. While Allied Universal has an
established customer base with significant density in traditional manned-guarding services, G4S will contribute to our
operational scale in Retail Cash solutions and Retail Technology solutions, which have grown since launching in 2015.
We see this as a new services platform, especially in our security technology services that we can cross-sell with North
American customers and improve Allied Universal’s services coverage. The expansion of Allied Universal’s
technology services platform capabilities will enable the combined company to offer superior client service, with
greater breadth, accountability, improved efficiency and cost savings. We have competitive advantages through strong
trajectory relative to competitors and potential disruptors and we transfer our knowledge and experience in the United
States to deploy our abilities to compete in adjacent markets.

**Meaningful cost synergy opportunity**

We intend to deploy operational and strategic best practices across Allied Universal and G4S to drive
additional growth, enable cross-selling capabilities, enhance operational performance and increase free cash flow
conversion. We estimate that the combination will unlock approximately $155 million in targeted annual cost savings
once G4S is fully integrated and our cost savings initiatives have been fully implemented. Allied Universal has a
strong track record of successful acquisition integration, including synergy realization. We anticipate that our
disciplined management of fixed and variable operating expenses, revenue and financing synergies, as well as
corporate overhead and headcount rationalization will primarily drive cost synergies. Historically, we have made a
significant number of acquisitions and we have well-developed systems and processes throughout our organization to
support integration efforts, resulting in more efficient synergy realization and helping drive overall margin
improvement.

The overlapping business functions in North America provide a significant opportunity for real estate and
personnel rationalization. Due to overlapping operations, we expect significant synergies in the following areas in the
North America region: general and administrative expenses, duplicative service contracts, insurance, and facilities
expense. Additionally, we will be able to eliminate any expenses in functional support areas that support G4S’s status
as a public listed company. Further, we believe opportunities exist to increase operating leverage through
diversification across investment in capabilities, such as additional training and technology deployments.

**Industry Overview**

**Market Overview**

The global contract security services market is large, has been stable and is expected to continue its consistent
growth supported by a number of favorable trends. The US security services market was estimated to generate
approximately $66 billion in revenue in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 4% to 5% compound annual growth rate
(“CAGR”) from 2021 to 2025. The US security services market for outsourced manned guarding generated over $28
billion in revenue in 2020 and grew at a 4.3% CAGR from 2017 to 2020. The security technology market in the US
is also large, with revenues estimated to be approximately $17 billion in 2020, and grew slightly quicker than the
manned guarding segment, at a CAGR of approximately 8% from 2017 to 2020. The market was estimated to be
comprised of approximately 42% manned guarding and 25% security technology. Internationally, the security services
market for manned guarding grew to $34 billion in revenue in 2020 and is expected to reach approximately $40 billion
in revenue in 2025, representing an estimated compound annual growth rate of 5% from 2021 to 2025.


-----

A heightened focus on security, both in the United States and globally, has been driven by high profile gun
violence, domestic terrorism events, a rise in workplace incidents and both peaceful and violent protest events, which
have led to increased spending on security. Our service offerings represent an important first line of defense against
potential security threats. Meanwhile, mega trends occurring around the world and positive growth tailwinds in the
distribution, manufacturing, healthcare and education sectors also support demand for increasing security. In addition,
organizations continue to outsource their security services primarily to alleviate administrative burdens and achieve
cost savings, while the compelling value proposition delivered through scale, broad service offerings and robust
technological infrastructure drive them to shift to highly professionalized providers.

Given the high-risk exposure of inadequate security, we believe that customers make purchasing decisions
based on service quality, reliability, and reputation, rather than price alone. It has been our experience that customers
seek out and maintain long-term relationships with quality providers. For example, industry switching rates have
historically been between 10% to 15% on average annually, and customer retention rates are higher for large customers
served under national contracts, according to a third party consulting study. Meanwhile, Allied Universal, as a scale
provider, experienced below average annual customer switching rates of between 5% to 10%.

We believe the industry’s stability in various economic cycles is underpinned by the recession-resistant
nature of security services, resulting in limited cyclicality and customer churn. Over a ten-year period, industry growth
has been consistent, and historically recession-resistant, experiencing only one year of flat-to-slightly declining
growth. The impact of economic downturns on labor markets, which includes higher employee retention, and
subsequently lower unbilled overtime, recruiting and training costs, historically have led to EBITDA margin
expansion, which has historically been sustained during a return to economic expansion. Our experience during 2020
demonstrates the resiliency of our business model. Despite lockdowns and office closures during the COVID
pandemic, security services remained an essential part of real estate management and asset protection. During this
period, we also experienced a temporary shift in demand from security services in connection with retail, travel and
leisure to grocery and other essential businesses. We also experienced an increase in demand for higher value-add
services such as temperature screening. During the summer of 2020, protests and other civil events drove demand for
our manned guarding services, providing further diversification and resiliency against office closings.

**Market Drivers**

The US security services and security technology integration and manned guarding market is expected to
grow at a CAGR of approximately 5% from 2021 through 2025. Several positive trends support this growth, including:
(i) baseline expansion from building stock growth, guard penetration in existing buildings, and wage rate growth
which is passed on through the mark-up model used to price security services; (ii) secular demand growth due to
heightened focus on security driven by increased acts of violence and media coverage, increasing regulatory and
insurance scrutiny; and (iii) increased outsourcing rate for security services. Furthermore, there is a trend toward the
centralization of security programs and integration of manned guarding with technology solutions, both of which favor
best-in-class national providers. As the national player with vertical markets expertise and differentiated integrated
security and technology solutions, we are well-positioned to benefit from favorable industry tailwinds.


-----

Globally, demand for security services has also increased steadily and is expected to grow at a CAGR of
4.9% between 2020 and 2024. Demand is driven by similar factors as in the United States as well as elevated safety
and security risks and concerns driven by geopolitical events such as refuge crises, increased wealth driven by
urbanization, global GDP growth, rising labor costs supporting demand for higher-value, technology-enabled,
integrated security solutions and demand for higher-value service lines driven by more advanced technology
capabilities.

The COVID pandemic demonstrated the industry’s resilience as the global security services market continued
to experience growth despite lockdowns throughout much of the world.

**Base-Line Industry Growth**

Base-line industry growth is driven by underlying economic growth, growing wage rates and increasing
building stock, as each new building adds incremental demand for the security services industry. While building stock
growth provides strong underlying support for the security services market, it is not necessary to sustain growth within
our existing customer bases. A growing economy drives up overall wage rates, increases statutory minimum wages
and provides union increases, all which are typically passed on to customers through a stable mark-up. Increased wage
rates are expected to continue driving further expansion of the manned guarding market and increase revenue
generation from existing clients.

**Growing Demand for Security Services**

Security services remain critical and non-discretionary as customers overwhelmingly value the role of
security officers in deterring criminal activity and other incidents, all the while providing assurance against real or
perceived security threats. In cases of security incidents, customers value the officers’ ability to provide immediate
response. Technology can enhance and significantly improve security but we believe there is no substitute for the
physical presence of well-trained and dedicated security personnel who can respond to threats in real-time.

The demand for security services continues to increase due to heightened security concerns stemming from
the ongoing threat of terrorism and high profile gun violence, large protest events, heightened importance of public
and workplace safety, refugee crises and the growing need to supplement services provided by the public sector.
Heightened media coverage of security lapses, growing costs of disruption, and stricter security requirements by
government institutions and private insurers have forced organizations to take greater responsibility for their own
security.

**Increased Outsourcing to Third-party Providers with National and Global Scale**

Currently, approximately 65% of manned security services in the United States are outsourced to professional
security services firms, and this outsourcing rate is expected to increase incrementally over time. The trend toward
outsourcing is expected to continue to drive growth in the industry due to the strong value proposition of contract
security service providers and non-core nature of security for the vast majority of companies.

Due to the growing complexity surrounding security-related issues and increased demand for vertical
segment expertise and customized guarding services, outsourcing security services to “best-in-class” providers
continues to be an attractive option for customers. Contract security services firms can offer customers improved
security, reduced non-core administrative burden, and competitive pricing through operating leverage, each of which
are compelling reasons supporting the trend toward outsourcing various business services. Outsourcing of non-core
functions has not only become a corporate best practice, but also a function of the public sector as governments look
to minimize cost. Outsourcing allows companies and governments to reduce labor costs and shift the administrative
burden of non-core functions to third-party vendors with more experience, operating leverage, and functional area
expertise.

As one of the few security and facility services providers with national and global scale, we believe the
combined Allied Universal and G4S business is well-positioned to benefit from the trend toward outsourcing security
services. For example, we are able to address customers’ increasingly complex security needs and their preference for


-----

best-in-class providers with strong reputations and vertical markets expertise, rather than local providers. In addition,
as national customers increasingly seek to consolidate vendors, they build relationships with national partners that can
reliably and consistently serve them across multiple regions. Finally, the increased centralization of procurement
continues to drive the shift in customer decision-making from a local level to a multi-region and national level,
providing an opportunity for national providers to increase customer penetration.

**Security Services Technology**

Due to the importance of having security officers physically present to deter and quickly respond to incidents,
technology has been used primarily to enhance and better enable manned security services. Security services providers
such as Allied Universal and G4S continue to broaden their portfolio of services by combining value-added offerings
like access controls, ID verification, video monitoring, and communications systems with traditional security officer
and patrol services. Customers seek integration between manned guarding services and complementary technology
solutions in order to improve and reduce the complexity of their security operations. Existing customer relationships
create the ability to cross-sell services for the installation, integration and maintenance of physical technology systems
that augment manned guarding services. Integrated technology solutions enhance the value delivered to customers
and foster customer retention. They provide a recurring revenue model for providers, as they require one-time sales
and installations but involve regular system services and maintenance.

**Industry Consolidation**

Over the past eight years, the contract security services industry has consolidated through increased M&A
activity. Given the sustained fragmented nature of the industry, this trend is expected to continue in the near to
intermediate term. Reflecting the strong customer preference for national and increasingly global scale providers and
the operational and cost advantages of having local density, large contract security services providers continue to gain
market share. Together, Allied Universal and G4S will hold a leading market position and we expect to further growth
market share in the security services industry in the United States and globally in connection with the business
combination.

Following the G4S Acquisition, Allied Universal has become the global leader in security services and the
acquisition reinforced our number one position in North America. Combined with G4S, we increased our scale and
density, further enhancing our ability to deliver consistent, high quality services across our operations infrastructure.

We have achieved industry-leading growth over the last decade through both organic and accretive M&A

Our national scale also enables us to serve strategic industry verticals such as high-rise offices, aerospace

our customers, providing a location-specific approach with the benefits of a global platform. Our local density enables
us to serve a wide range of client sizes while achieving operational leverage at the branch level by keeping overhead

**Consistent, Recession-Resistant Industry**

The resilient nature of the security services market was demonstrated during the COVID pandemic, which
reaffirmed the essential nature of services provided by Allied Universal. Early in the pandemic, security professionals
were generally deemed essential by health authorities and continued to deliver security services to a range of
customers. Minor business disruptions at the onset of lockdowns led to a slight pullback in hours relative to the preCOVID period. Allied Universal has so far successfully managed the pandemic and performance has been highly
resilient both in top line growth and in margin expansion. Hours have since rebounded and even increased in some
regions as COVID-related restrictions have eased and economic activity continues to rebound, while increased
security concerns remain. Services have continued to expand as customers seek a partner to help implement and
execute new policies and procedures at guarded sites, in addition to offering additional services such as temperature
checks. An enhanced focus on innovative technology solutions drives further upside for security providers that offer
fully integrated solutions.

Allied Universal’s resilient top-line is driven by the contractual revenue streams with daily re-occurrence of
services, the critical nature of security to operations, and the low cost of security services relative to the high cost of
failure. The company typically benefits from rising wages as increases are passed on to clients, who generally expect
a 2% to 3% annual increase in billing rates, in-line with wage growth. Tightening labor markets result in stable
margins, while softer markets typically drive margin expansion as the increased supply of labor reduces the spread
between bill rates and employee pay rates.

**Compelling Growth Tailwinds in the United States and Across the Globe**

The critical and non-discretionary nature of security services to customers is driving stable, consistent growth
both in the United States and globally. The US security services market generated approximately $66 billion in revenue
in 2020, and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 5% between 2021 and 2025. Globally, the manned guarding market
generated approximately $34 billion in revenue in 2020, and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 5% from 2021 to 2025.
The international technology security services market generated approximately $8 billion in revenue in 2020, and is
expected to grow at a CAGR of 4% from 2021 to 2025. Demand for high quality security services continues to grow
through heightened focus on security, increasing public safety awareness and the growing need to supplement services
provided by the public sector. The trend of outsourcing to high quality providers such as Allied Universal will continue
to be supported by a compelling value proposition, increasing security complexity and centralization of security
programs. There is a low risk of technology disruption as only manned security is considered an active deterrent to
perceived security threats. Further, technology solutions enhance rather than displace manned guarding and Allied
Universal provides customers with a best-in-class technology integrated service offering. These tailwinds, combined
with attractive end-market growth across diversified verticals, support attractive market growth across all key
geographies serviced by the combined company.

**Highly Diversified Revenue Mix Across High Growth Customer Base**

In the United States, Allied Universal has a highly diversified revenue mix across all major regions and
metropolitan areas, end markets, and customers. We have limited customer concentration, as our top 10 customers
account for 10.7% of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020, with no customer contributing more than 1.9%
of revenue during that period. Finally, we serve a variety of distinct vertical segments, none of which account for more
than 11% of revenue. This end market diversification shields us from industry-specific shocks and allows us to provide
vertical-specific solutions necessitated by the increasing complexity of security issues in different end markets. We
also benefit from our commercial real estate customers’ diverse tenant base and most of our mall clients being
considered “class A” (representing high sales per square foot), which achieve steadier foot traffic and higher guard
penetration.

The combined company will benefit from an expanded blue-chip client base, including a significant portion
of the Fortune 500, and vertical market clients, as well as a diversified revenue mix across North America, Asia
Pacific, Europe & Middle East, and Africa. The largest revenue mix by customer type is major corporate & industrial,
which accounted for roughly 21% of combined revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020, followed by
government, with 13% of combined revenue, financial institutions, with 9% of combined revenue, retail and malls,
with 7% of combined revenue, technology, media and telecommunication, with 6% of combined revenue, commercial
real estate, with 6% of combined revenue, transportation and logistics, with 6% of combined revenue, chemical and
energy/utilities, with 6% of combined revenue, healthcare, with 5% of combined revenue, manufacturing and
industrial, with 3% of combined revenue, aerospace and defense, with 2% of combined revenue, and education, with

estimates.

**Stable and Predictable Financial Performance Coupled with Strong Free Cash Flow Generation**

_Consistent history of growth: Allied Universal has repeatedly demonstrated the ability to deliver growth,_
consistent and improving profitability, and strong cash flow. The nature of our customer contracts fosters a highly
visible financial model. Our recurring revenue base is supported by an above-average customer retention rate. To drive
revenue growth, both companies target new client wins, in particular the expansion of the premier customers portfolio
within Allied Universal, expanded scope of work and customer penetration with existing clients, added
complementary technology solutions, and consistent increases in price in line with wage rate growth and the delivery
of high- quality services. These organic growth drivers, coupled with our ability to execute upon accretive acquisition
opportunities, have contributed to strong revenue and Adjusted EBITDA growth. From 2005 to 2020, Allied
Universal’s standalone organic revenue CAGR was approximately 6% and from 2017 to 2020, Allied Universal
consistently grew the spread between bill rates and wage rates per hour by approximately 4.5%. Allied Universal’s
disciplined acquisition strategy combined with strong organic growth has allowed us to become the fastest growing
security services company in the industry while maintaining strong free cash flow generation. The combination
between Allied Universal and G4S is expected to drive further topline and profitability growth through significant
cross-selling and cost synergy opportunities.

_Highly-variable cost structure drives predictable margins: Bill rate, which is the price we charge to our_
customers per hour per security officer, is priced as a mark-up on security officer pay rates, which is the wage we pay
to security guards per hour. From 2016 to 2020, Allied Universal’s mark-up has remained constant at 1.48x. This
stable mark-up reflects the strong track record of passing on cost increases to clients and expanding margins. Our
ability to pass through labor costs and other variable expenses to our clients allows us to generate consistent
profitability and produce cash flows with low volatility. This consistency helps us maintain stable operating margins
and provides a baseline level of profitability from which further margin expansion can be achieved as we continue to
increase our operating leverage and scale, while reducing general and administrative expenses.

_Capital-light business model supports strong cash flow: Our minimal capital requirements and strong_
working capital management support our strong cash flow profile. Capital expenditures over the past three years were
approximately 1.8% of annual revenue on average, with cash capital expenditures representing about half of such
capital expenditures and the remaining portion funded through capital leases. We also have minimal and predictable
net working capital needs, which provides further visibility into free cash flow.

**Proven Platform for Continued Organic Growth and Disciplined Approach to M&A**

We have demonstrated consistent growth, both organically and inorganically. We have historically grown
approximately 6% organically, driven by our best-in-class service offering, continued scale increase, technologically
advanced offerings and strong secular tailwinds. Utilizing a disciplined approach, we have demonstrated a strong track
record of sourcing, executing and integrating both tuck-in and transformative acquisitions. Through these acquisitions,
we have achieved meaningful cost synergies as well as customer, end market and geographic diversity. We have
completed 72 acquisitions since 2007 with a majority being proprietary opportunities acquired at mid-single digit
purchase multiples. We have historically achieved approximately 98% revenue retention within the 12 months postacquisition, further demonstrating our ability to successfully integrate targets onto our platform while continuing to
provide high quality service to customers. We continue to maintain a propriety pipeline of potential targets as we
continue to execute our roll-up strategy.

**Highly Experienced Management Team**

We have a highly experienced and well-respected management team with a proven track record and
meaningful equity ownership. Management was responsible for developing and implementing the expansion strategy
that has led to industry-leading growth for the company. The team has a strong track record of continuously evolving
and growing the business through both organic and M&A strategies, and is experienced in integrating accretive
acquisitions. The team is committed to delivering continued growth, and has significant equity ownership in Allied
Universal. Outside of the executive management group, there is a deep bench of leadership and operational talent
throughout the organization given the selection of the best security specialists in connection with the merger of
AlliedBarton and Universal in 2016.

**Growth Strategy**

**Proven Ability to Win New Clients and Grow with Existing Clients**

Our underlying organic growth has historically been driven by hours growth attributable to (i) developing a
world-class sales and marketing organization, (ii) leveraging our competitive advantages to win new customers,
including premier customers, (iii) expanding customer penetration and leveraging cross-selling opportunities with
clients by delivering customized service offerings specific to customer needs, and (iv) maintaining steady underlying
customer retention rates in the 90% range in the long term, and pricing growth driven by passing on pay rate increases
to customers. In order to drive new customer wins for Allied Universal, our sales organization is structured by
salespeople focused on premier customers, salespeople focused on regional and local accounts, vertical market
specialists, and regional specialists. Our sales pipeline is robust, with the pipeline typically representing a multiple of
the annual new starts target. Premier customers sales efforts target customers with facilities in multiple locations
throughout the United States, who increasingly desire consistency of service, fewer points of contact and alignment
with a national partner providing a full suite of capabilities. As we have expanded our geographical footprint and
adapted sales and client service capabilities, we have become well-positioned to be the leading provider to premier
customers . With our existing customers, we seek to grow customer penetration by increasing the number of customer
sites served and thus the hours that our security officers cover, and adding on different types of security services. Our
organic growth is supported by underlying customer retention rates in the 90% range over the past 10 years. Given
the multi-year contractual nature of many of our large contracts, we have visibility over a significant portion of our


-----

revenue . We proactively manage contracts in advance of renewal, rebid or expiration. Finally, organic growth has
been driven by increasing pricing in line with security officer pay rate increases. We have demonstrated a history of
successfully increasing bill rates with pay rates, as evidenced by stable mark-up rate and increasing mark-up spread
over the long term.

We have grown our revenue at a CAGR of approximately 6% between 2005 and 2020. We believe we are
well-positioned to continue achieving measured growth by capitalizing on our strong reputation, enhanced operational
capabilities, vertical-specific service expertise and premier customers platform. In addition to increasing hours by
adding new accounts, benefiting from increased outsourcing, we will continue to leverage our significant experience
managing pricing dynamics to drive growth.

**Service Line Expansion**

The combination of Allied Universal and G4S is expected to generate meaningful cross-selling opportunities.
The combined comprehensive offering of security solutions across a global platform will allow the combined business
to serve as a one-stop-shop for existing customers served by the combined group, as well as new clients looking for a
global provider to serve their security needs. The expertise of each organization in serving specific end markets and
geographies will increase the overall reach and ability to serve global clients across a range of industries with a host
of complimentary services.

Our industry-leading manned guarding services provide a platform from which to continue offering
additional services. To date, we have utilized this platform to offer additional services, such as physical technology
systems, including video surveillance, CCTV picture capture and monitoring, robot patrolling, GPS based patrol and
reporting, online threat monitoring, and managing access control points and centralized security operation.
Additionally, we also offer integration services to design, install and service fully integrated technology-based
monitoring systems. Finally, we provide digital solutions and remote monitoring through MaRC.

Our acquisition of Securadyne Systems (“Securadyne”) in April 2019 further strengthened our ability to
consult, design, deploy, integrate and maintain electronic security systems for our customers. We believe the
Securadyne acquisition provided us with the footprint and scalable infrastructure that enables us to deliver
complementary security integration services to a significantly larger portion of the existing approximately 50,000
client sites where we provide manned guarding services today.

In addition to system installation, maintenance, robots, and monitoring, we have integrated technology into
our manned guarding services and are in the process of deploying a custom Incident Management System (“IMS”)
that provides real-time incident data reporting and situational awareness information powered by artificial intelligence.
The proprietary application, HeliAUS, provides in-depth incident reporting, data collection, and predictive analytics,
allowing managers and clients to spot trends and react quickly, while improving workforce supervision and improving
liability management. The highly scalable platform is delivered to customers via a monthly subscription and is billed
directly to users as a supplement to manned guarding services.

Beyond our technology offerings, we intend to continue to grow our janitorial and staffing services, which
are a portfolio of offerings including cleaning services and a provider of skilled talent across a diverse set of industries
such as traditional janitorial functions as well as highly specialized cleaning services such as bio- hazard disposal, IT
room cleaning, and recycling programs.

**Proven Platform for Disciplined M&A**

We benefit from our significant experience in successfully integrating acquisitions while maintaining
relationships with both existing and acquired customers. The largely fragmented security services industry has
historically provided opportunities to supplement our strong organic growth with a disciplined acquisition strategy. A
large and fragmented international market, as well as relevant adjacent markets, provides additional opportunity for
targeted expansion. Our approach to acquisitions has been highly methodical and focused on scale-building and infill
acquisitions. Integration occurs quickly, generally within 30 days for a typical tuck-in acquisition, making for a
seamless transition for customers.


-----

Allied Universal has proven experience executing all types of transactions, including 72 small tuck-ins and
large transformational acquisitions since 2007. On average, these acquisitions were completed at credit accretive, midsingle digit multiples. In addition to many small and medium tuck-ins, we have a proven track record of successfully
executing and integrating transformative acquisitions, as evidenced by the combination of AlliedBarton and Universal
in August 2016, as well as the large tuck-in acquisition of USSA, formerly the fourth-largest manned guarding
provider in the United States in 2018. The combination of our smaller tuck-in acquisitions along with our ability to
acquire targets of scale, such as USSA, demonstrate our disciplined ability to take advantage of growth opportunities
as they become available.

We believe we are an “acquirer of choice” due to our strong reputation and track record and are the bestpositioned consolidator in a highly fragmented market. A significant portion of our past acquisitions have been
completed on a proprietary basis. Additionally, we estimate that over 40% of the outsourced manned guarding services
market in the United States is comprised of over 7,000 firms and roughly 60% of the security technology services
market is comprised of over 3,000 firms, providing a large opportunity set for further accretive consolidation. We
benefit from significant industrial logic from on-boarding sub-scale providers onto our scalable platform which drives
the ability to expand margins of acquired companies. We believe the combination of Allied Universal and G4S will
allow us to execute further our disciplined and well-demonstrated M&A playbook in key markets globally.

**Recent Developments**

**The Transactions**

On April 6, 2021, we completed the G4S Acquisition. See “—G4S Acquisition.” In connection with the G4S
Acquisition, on April 8, 2021, we entered into the new senior secured credit facilities (the “New Senior Secured Credit
Facilities”), which consist of (i) a $950.0 million seven year senior secured U.S. dollar term loan facility (the “New
First Lien USD Term Facility”) and a €715.5 million seven year senior secured euro term loan facility (the “New First
Lien Euro Term Facility” and, together with the New First Lien USD Term Facility, the “New First Lien Term Loan
Facilities”) and (ii) a €300.0 million five year senior secured euro revolving credit facility (the “New Revolving Credit
Facility”). In addition, we entered into (i) a new senior secured bridge loan credit facility, pursuant to which secured
bridge loans in the amounts of $900,000,000, $775,000,000, €813,008,135 and £367,647,060 were made available to
us for borrowing (the “Secured Bridge Loan Credit Facility”) and (ii) a new senior unsecured bridge loan credit
facility, pursuant to which unsecured bridge loans in the amount of $1,285,000,000 were made available to us for
borrowing (together with the Secured Bridge Loan Credit Facility, the “Bridge Credit Facilities”). As of the date of
this offering circular, we have incurred secured bridge loans in the amounts of $900,000,000, $775,000,000 and
£367,647,060 and unsecured bridge loans in the amount of $1,285,000,000, and we may borrow up to €813,008,135
under the Secured Bridge Loan Credit Facility.

On April 8, 2021, we also increased the total availability under our five year asset based lending credit facility
from $750.0 million to $1,000.0 million and expect to further increase such facility to $1,500.0 million (such further
increase, the “ABL Credit Facility Increase” and such facility as further amended by the ABL Credit Facility Increase,
the “ABL Credit Facility”). However, there can be no assurance that such increase will be consummated, and this
offering of the notes is not conditioned upon the completion of the ABL Credit Facility Increase.

The amounts borrowed under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Bridge Credit Facilities,
together with cash on hand and certain equity contributions, were used to (i) pay the acquisition consideration in
connection with the G4S Acquisition and (ii) pay related fees, costs, premiums and expenses in connection therewith.
Such net proceeds will also be used for the voluntary or mandatory repayment, redemption, defeasance, tender or
acquisition by Allied Universal in full of certain existing third party indebtedness of G4S (the “Existing G4S Debt”
and such repayment, redemption, defeasance, tender or acquisition, the “G4S Refinancing”). See “Description of
Certain Other Indebtedness” for a description of the Existing G4S Debt. We expect approximately $2,746 million of
the Existing G4S Debt will remain outstanding on the issue date of the notes offered hereby, with all such indebtedness
expected to be repaid within approximately 150 days following the issue date of the notes offered hereby. However,
certain of the Existing G4S Debt may not be capable of voluntary prepayment on its terms, except in connection with
certain adverse changes in taxation and as a result such repayment would be subject to the implementation of a tender
offer in respect of such Existing G4S Debt and/or certain amendments to the instruments governing such Existing
G4S Debt.


-----

The proceeds from this offering of the notes will be used to (i) repay in full borrowings outstanding under
the Bridge Credit Facilities and terminate all available borrowings thereunder and (ii) pay related fees, costs, premiums
and expenses.

In this offering circular, we collectively refer to the entry into the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, the
G4S Refinancing, the ABL Credit Facility Increase, the entry into and the subsequent repayment of the Bridge Credit
Facilities and the termination of all available borrowings thereunder using the net proceeds of this offering of the
notes, and in each case, the use of proceeds therefrom, as the “Financing Transactions” and the Financing Transactions,
together with the related transactions in connection with the G4S Acquisition, the “Transactions.” See “Use of
Proceeds,” “Capitalization” and “Description of Certain Other Indebtedness” for more information.

**Recent and Expected Acquisitions**

On January 16, 2021, we completed a purchase of the outstanding equity interests in SecurAmerica, LLC,
SecurAmerica Corporation and ERMC LLC (collectively, “SecurAmerica”) for a preliminary purchase price subject
to certain post-closing adjustments of approximately $352 million. Based in Atlanta, Georgia, SecurAmerica is a
provider of security, asset protection and janitorial services with offices located throughout the United States. In
connection with the purchase of SecurAmerica, we also deposited $31.5 million into an escrow account to fund the
future purchase of substantially all of the assets of SecurAmerica TN LLC and ERMC TN LLC (collectively,
“SecurAmerica TN”). Also based in Atlanta, Georgia, SecurAmerica TN is a provider of security and janitorial
services. The transaction is expected to close during 2021, subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions.

Subsequent to December 31, 2020 and prior to the date of this offering circular, we completed two other
tuck-in acquisitions for an aggregate purchase price of $10.8 million.

**Our Investor Group**

Our major equity investors include the following:

**Warburg Pincus LLC**

Warburg Pincus LLC is a leading global private equity firm focused on growth investing. The firm has more
than $58 billion in private equity assets under management. The firm’s active portfolio of more than 190 companies
is highly diversified by stage, sector and geography. Warburg Pincus is an experienced partner to management teams
seeking to build durable companies with sustainable value. Founded in 1966, Warburg Pincus has raised 19 private
equity funds, which have invested more than $81 billion in over 890 companies in more than 40 countries. The firm
is headquartered in New York with offices in Amsterdam, Beijing, Berlin, Hong Kong, Houston, London,
Luxembourg, Mumbai, Mauritius, San Francisco, São Paulo, Shanghai and Singapore.

**CDPQ**

CDPQ was created in 1965 and is one of Canada’s leading institutional asset managers and a mandatary of
the Government of Québec. Pursuant to its constituting act, CDPQ’s mission is to receive moneys on deposit as
provided by law and manage them with a view to achieving optimal return on capital within the framework of
depositors’ investment policies while at the same time contributing to Québec’s economic development. As at
December 31, 2019, CDPQ had 41 depositors primarily consisting of Québec public and parapublic pension and
insurance plans. Depositors’ total and net assets were C$392.6 billion and C$340.1 billion, respectively, as at
December 31, 2019. As one of Canada’s leading institutional fund managers, CDPQ invests globally in a wide range
of asset classes, including major financial markets, private equity, infrastructure, real estate and private debt. In private
equity, CDPQ has approximately C$50.2 billion in net assets under management and invests in a broad range of sectors
worldwide, with a focus on Canada, the United States and Europe. It seeks to partner with and invest in unique
companies, and focuses on helping to build and grow great businesses over the long term.

**Partners Group AG**

Founded in 1996, Partners Group is a global private markets investment management firm with $95 billion
in assets under management in private equity, private real estate, private infrastructure and private debt. The firm
manages a broad range of customized portfolios for an international clientele of institutional investors. Partners Group
is headquartered in Zug, Switzerland and has offices in Denver, Houston, Toronto, New York, São Paulo, London,
Guernsey, Paris, Luxembourg, Milan, Munich, Dubai, Mumbai, Singapore, Manila, Shanghai, Seoul, Tokyo and
Sydney. The firm employs over 1,500 people and is listed on the SIX Swiss Exchange (symbol: PGHN) with a major
ownership by its partners and employees.

**J. Safra Group**

The J. Safra Group (“Safra” and, collectively with Warburg Pincus LLC, CDPQ and Partners Group, the
“Investor Group”), with total assets under management of over $270 billion, is controlled by the Joseph Safra family.
Safra consists of privately owned banks under the Safra name and investment holdings in asset-based business sectors
such as real estate and agribusiness. Safra’s banking interests count over 160 locations globally and there are more
than 35,000 employees associated with Safra. With deep relationships in markets worldwide, Safra is able to greatly
enhance the value of businesses which are part of it.

expense and depreciation and amortization, as further adjusted to exclude certain non-cash items and certain
cash expenses management considers non-recurring, unusual or otherwise not indicative of our ongoing
operating performance and to reflect the full expected effect of cost reduction and profit-enhancing initiatives,
acquisitions, disposals and related cost and revenue synergies. Specific adjustments for the fiscal years ended
December 31, 2019 and 2020 include adjustments for transaction, integration and restructuring costs, sponsor
and director fees, non-cash equity-based compensation, legal settlements and related fees, certain adjustments
related to the implementation of Allied Universal’s accounting standards, loss on disposal of property and
equipment, loss on early extinguishment of debt, (gain) loss on disposal of businesses, and miscellaneous
other non-recurring adjustments, as further adjusted to give effect to start-up costs and lease costs, profitimprovement initiatives, unrealized synergies from certain acquired businesses, management’s estimates of
EBITDA from certain acquired businesses generated prior to their acquisition date, management’s estimates
of EBITDA from certain businesses acquired in 2021, profits related to disposed businesses, and other nonrecurring adjustments, which are described in further detail below. Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA
has been determined based on the combined statements of operations of Allied Universal and G4S for the
year ended December 31, 2020 as adjusted as described under ”Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined
Financial Information,” and as further adjusted to reflect certain non-recurring adjustments and unrealized
synergies in connection with the Financing Transactions and G4S Acquisition as described in further detail
below. We define Pro Forma Combined Adjusted Revenue as Allied Universal’s historical revenue, as
adjusted to give effect to businesses acquired during 2020 and 2021 by Allied Universal, plus G4S’s


-----

historical revenue, as adjusted to give effect to revenue from businesses held for sale by G4S, onerous
contracts, revenue from businesses disposed of by G4S during 2020 and 2021 and constant currency
exchange rate adjustments. You are encouraged to evaluate these adjustments and the reasons we consider
them appropriate for supplemental analysis. In evaluating these non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures, you
should be aware that in the future we may incur expenses that are the same as or similar to some of the
adjustments in this presentation. Our presentation of these non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures should not be
construed as an inference that our future results will be unaffected by unusual or non-recurring items.

We present these non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures because we believe they assist management and
investors when analyzing our performance by providing meaningful information that facilitates the
comparability of underlying business results from period to period. We recognize these measures are not
measurements of financial performance under GAAP and IFRS and there are limitations associated with the
use of non-GAAP and non-IFRS financial measures. Some of these limitations are:

 - other companies may use different methods to calculate similar non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures,
and the measures we present may not be directly comparable with the measures presented by these
other companies as a result;

 - such measures do not reflect our cash expenditures, or future requirements for capital expenditures or
contractual commitments;

 - such measures do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

 - such measures do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary to
service interest payments, on our debts;

 - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and
amortized will often have to be replaced in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash
requirements for such replacements;

 - non-cash compensation is and will remain a key element of our overall long-term incentive
compensation package, although we exclude it as an expense when evaluating our ongoing operating
performance for a particular period;

 - such measures do not reflect the impact of certain cash charges resulting from matters we consider not
to be indicative of our ongoing operations; and

 - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their
usefulness as comparative measures.

Allied Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA are adjusted to reflect certain
acquisitions and certain unrealized acquisition synergies anticipated to be achieved in connection therewith.
We present these adjustments as they will be permitted as adjustments to “EBITDA” under the indentures
that will govern the notes offered hereby, although the non-GAAP and non-IFRS measures included herein
may be defined differently than the corresponding terms under such indentures, and to enable investors to
understand the covenants that will apply to us, and not as a projection of future results. We will be required to
make cash expenditures to achieve such cost savings, and these cash costs are not reflected in Allied Adjusted
EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA. In addition, we will not fully realize such cost
savings within 12 months of the completion of the Financing Transactions and the G4S Acquisition, and may
not do so at all. Accordingly, you should not view our presentation of this adjustment as a projection that we
will achieve these acquisition synergies. Our ability to realize these acquisition synergies is subject to
significant uncertainties and you should not place undue reliance on the adjustments in evaluating our
anticipated results. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industries—We may not realize
the expected benefits, revenue or cost synergies related to recently completed or future acquisitions” and
“Risk Factors—Risks Related to the G4S Acquisition—We may fail to realize all of the anticipated benefits


-----

of the G4S Acquisition or those benefits may take longer to realize than expected. We may also encounter
significant difficulties in integrating the G4S business.”

Because of these limitations, these non-GAAP and non-IFRS financial measures should not be considered in
isolation or as substitutes for, or as superior to, the presentation of results determined in accordance with
GAAP or IFRS, as applicable.

headcount, $28 million for corporate headcount, $28 million for non-headcount and $14 million for

We present G4S Adjusted EBITDA as a supplemental measure of G4S’s performance that is not required by
or presented in accordance with IFRS. We define G4S Adjusted EBITDA as profit / (loss) before interest expense,
net, income tax (benefit) expense and depreciation and amortization, as further adjusted to exclude certain non-cash
items and certain cash expenses management considers non-recurring, unusual or otherwise not indicative of our
ongoing operating performance and to reflect the full expected effect of cost reduction and profit-enhancing
initiatives, acquisitions, disposals and related cost and revenue synergies. Specific adjustments for the years ended
December 31, 2019 and 2020 include adjustments for transaction and integration costs, director fees, non-cash
equity-based compensation, legal settlements and related fees, loss (gain) on disposal of property and equipment,
loss (gain) on contingent consideration, certain IFRS adjustments, start-up costs, lease costs, management’s
estimates of EBITDA related to disposed businesses, constant currency exchange rate adjustments and other nonrecurring adjustments described below. You are encouraged to evaluate these adjustments and the reasons we
consider them appropriate for supplemental analysis. In evaluating these non-IFRS measures, you should be aware
that in the future we may incur expenses that are the same as or similar to some of the adjustments in this
presentation. Our presentation of these non-IFRS measures should not be construed as an inference that our future
results will be unaffected by unusual or non-recurring items.

We present G4S Adjusted EBITDA because we believe it assists management and investors when analyzing
our performance by providing meaningful information that facilitates the comparability of underlying business
results from period to period. We recognize G4S Adjusted EBITDA is not a measurement of financial performance
under IFRS and there are limitations associated with the use of non-IFRS financial measures. Some of these
limitations are:

    - other companies may use different methods to calculate similar non-IFRS measures, and the measures
we present may not be directly comparable with the measures presented by these other companies as a
result;

    - such measures do not reflect our cash expenditures, or future requirements for capital expenditures or
contractual commitments;

    - such measures do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

    - such measures do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary to
service interest payments, on our debts;

    - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and
amortized will often have to be replaced in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash
requirements for such replacements;


-----

  - non-cash compensation is and will remain a key element of our overall long-term incentive
compensation package, although we exclude it as an expense when evaluating our ongoing operating
performance for a particular period;

  - such measures do not reflect the impact of certain cash charges resulting from matters we consider not
to be indicative of our ongoing operations; and

  - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their
usefulness as comparative measures.

Because of these limitations, non-IFRS financial measures should not be considered in isolation or as
substitutes for, or as superior to, the presentation of results determined in accordance with IFRS.

_offering circular._

**Risks Related to Our Business and Industries**

**The COVID-19 pandemic, its scope and duration and the uncertainty related thereto may adversely affect**
**our business, results of operations, cash flows, liquidity and financial condition.**

The Company continues to closely monitor developments related to the COVID-19 pandemic to assess any
potential impact on its business. While the Company currently does not anticipate that the COVID-19 pandemic will
have a material adverse impact on its business, as a result of the evolving and highly uncertain nature of the COVID19 pandemic, no assurance may be made regarding potential exposure or the indirect effects of the outbreak on the
Company’s business, results of operations, cash flows, liquidity and financial condition.

The COVID-19 pandemic may heighten the potential adverse effects of the other risks on our business,
including, but not limited to, the likelihood of and impact from:

  - overall economic conditions, globally and in the United States, which have been and will likely continue to
be adversely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and related shutdowns;

  - our ability to maintain sufficient key personnel due to employee illness, quarantine requirements, worker
absences, enhancements to unemployment compensation benefits and other government relief programs,
social-distancing, travel or other restrictions;

  - reduced availability and productivity of labor;

  - continued or expanded closures of our customers’ facilities;

  - our customers’ demand and ability to pay for our services, or attempts by our customers to defer payments
owed to us;

  - our ability to obtain new customers, expand, or otherwise execute strategic plans;

  - our ability to comply with new legal or regulatory requirements enacted in connection with the COVID-19
pandemic;

  - legal actions, claims or proceedings related to the COVID-19 pandemic; and

  - the ability of third parties on which we rely, including our suppliers and business partners, to timely meet
