**Conforming Accounting Policies**

The following adjustments have been made to align G4S’s historical balance sheet as of December 31,
2020 and statement of operations for the year ended December 31, 2020 to Allied Universal’s accounting policies
after taking into effect the impacts of purchase accounting:

**B.** **Uniforms.** Represents an adjustment to record a reversal of accumulated depreciation related to
capitalized uniform costs as Allied Universal’s policy is to depreciate uniforms over three years
whereas G4S expenses uniforms over two years. The balance sheet impact is an estimated increase
of $21.8 million to Property and equipment, net, offset by a $5.5 million decrease to Deferred tax
assets. The net impact to the statement of operations is an estimated reduction of $2.6 million to
Direct expenses.

**C.** **Leases. Represents an adjustment to record the reversal of G4S’s lease related balances recognized**
in accordance with IFRS 16 – Leases (“IFRS 16”) to align with the recognition of leases under ASC
840, _Leases (“ASC 840”), as applied by Allied Universal. The balance sheet impact results in a_
derecognition of Right of use assets (Property and equipment, net) and net investments in finance
lease assets (Deposits and other long-term assets) of $309.3 million and $8.2 million, respectively,
that was offset by an additional recognition of $17.7 million of net investment in finance lease asset
in Property and equipment, net. There was an additional derecognition of a short-term and longterm IFRS 16 lease liability of $118.6 million and $260.3 million, respectively, offset by a
recognition of short-term and long-term finance (capital) lease liabilities per ASC 840 of $6.8


-----

million and $19.1 million, respectively. There was a further derecognition of Deferred tax assets of
$19.1 million to reflect the tax impacts of the reversals. The net impact to the statement of operations
involves a reversal of depreciation on right of use assets presented as Direct expenses of $63.1
million, a reversal of General and administrative expenses of $42.1 million, and a reversal of Interest
expense recognized on lease liabilities of $22.6 million. Such reversal has been offset by the
recognition of operating lease rental expenses presented in Direct expenses and in General and
administrative expenses of $84.2 million and $54.9 million, respectively.

**D.** **Goodwill Impairment.** Represents an adjustment to record a reversal of goodwill impairment
analyzed at the cash generating unit level per International Accounting Standards Board (“IAS”) 36

          - Impairment of Assets due to the expectation that impairment analysis at the reporting unit level per
U.S. GAAP would not result in any impairment. The adjustment results in an increase to Goodwill
of $78.7 million on the balance sheet, and a corresponding reversal of Goodwill impairment of $74.1
million, net of $4.6 million of currency translation impact on the statement of operations.

**E.** **Onerous Contracts. Represents an adjustment to remove the current and non-current provision of**
$4.1 million and $24.5 million, respectively, relating to onerous contracts recognized by G4S in
accordance with IAS 37 – Provisions (“IAS 37”) but not recognized under U.S. GAAP. This balance
sheet impact is offset by an associated $5.5 million reduction in the Deferred tax asset balance. To
record the impact of the reversal of onerous contract provision balances in the statement of
operations for the period ended December 31, 2020, the expense of $9.0 million recognized during
2020 for future losses is reversed from General and administration expense and is instead,
recognized as an in-year loss in Direct expense.

**F.** **Defined Benefit Schemes.** Represents an adjustment to record a $61.6 million increase in Other
expense, net. This adjustment also results in an additional tax expense of $7.7 million. There is no
balance sheet impact as a result of this adjustment, as any adjustments made to Other comprehensive
income would be eliminated due to the application of purchase accounting.

**G.** **Hedge Accounting. Represents an adjustment to record $21.8 million in Interest expense as a result**
of the unwinding of hedge accounting from Other comprehensive income into Interest expense. This
adjustment results in an associated tax expense of $6.4 million. There is no balance sheet impact as
a result of this adjustment, as any adjustments made to Other comprehensive income would be
eliminated due to the application of purchase accounting.

**H.** **Cloud Computing Costs.** Represents an adjustment to reverse a balance of $31.3 million from
Intangible assets, net for capitalized implementation costs on cloud computing software provided to
G4S as a service. Such costs are not capitalizable for entities such as Allied Universal who have not
yet adopted ASU 2018-15. This reversal is offset by an associated $8.2 million increase in deferred
tax assets.

**I.** **Unremitted Earnings.** Represents an adjustment of $47.4 million to record the recognition of
deferred tax on unremitted earnings in accordance with ASC 740.

**Business Overview**

Allied Universal is North America’s leading security and facility services provider. With over 250,000
security professionals and offices located throughout the United States as well as internationally (Canada, Mexico,
and the United Kingdom), Allied Universal serves approximately 14,800 clients and is responsible for protecting more
than 50,000 client sites covering multiple specialty sectors such as higher education, healthcare, retail, commercial
real estate, government, and corporate campuses, including a significant portion of the Fortune 500 companies. Allied
Universal’s services span manned guarding, innovative technology systems, risk and consulting, janitorial and staffing
services, integration services, and digital solutions and remote monitoring.

We are responsible for providing “best-in-class” security services that allow clients to completely outsource
the recruiting, screening, hiring, training, uniforming, scheduling and supervision of security officers. Our security
officers work on-location at customer sites and are responsible for observing, detecting, deterring and reporting and
responding to perceived, potential or actual security threats. We also provide specialized security services such as
vehicle patrol, visitor management, K-9 security services, top security facility cleared security professionals, and joint
security programs. We have an operational presence in all 50 US states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico and
have a growing presence in Canada, Latin America, and the United Kingdom.

In addition to providing manned guarding services, we provide comprehensive technology solutions to our
customers, including video surveillance, CCTV picture capture and monitoring, robot patrolling, GPS-based patrol
and reporting, management of access control points and centralized security operations. We also offer systems
integration services to design, install and service fully integrated technology-based monitoring systems, along with
digital solutions and remote monitoring through our MaRC. We are able to leverage our large manned guarding
customer base and service platform to cross-sell these additional system integration services. Finally, we offer a range
of ancillary services, including temporary and permanent staffing, event staffing and security, janitorial services, and
consulting and investigation solutions.

Allied Universal was formed in August 2016 through the combination of AlliedBarton and Universal, which
brought together two of the leading providers in the security services industry. AlliedBarton, founded in 1957, and
Universal, founded in 1965, were leaders in the industry in customer service, organic growth, customer and employee
retention, accretive M&A, and had a highly complementary and diverse set of blue chip customers. The combined
company became the largest provider of security officer services in North America and has continued to grow since,
both organically and through M&A. In the fourth quarter of 2018, Allied Universal acquired U.S. Security Associates
Holdings, Inc., a leading North American provider of security solutions, including manned security, consulting,
investigations, and disaster and emergency response services. Since 2007, the company has successfully executed 72
acquisitions, including small and large tuck-ins. In the fourth quarter of 2019, Allied announced the acquisition of
SOS Security, which brought a complementary approach and further scale to Allied Universal. As of 2020, Allied
Universal has an estimated 31% share of the highly fragmented outsourced manned guarding security services market
in the United States, with a track record of growth driven both organically and through acquisitions.

**Recent Developments**

**Characteristics of Allied Universal’s Revenues and Expenses**

**Revenues**

We generate revenues primarily from customer contracts obligating us to provide security officer services at
agreed-upon hourly billing rates. Our standard customer contract has a one-year term but may be terminated by either
our customer or us with 30 days’ advance notice. Many of our larger contracts are multi-year but also allow for
cancellation by either party with 30 to 90 days’ advance notice. We base our customer billings on the underlying
contractual terms, which generally include a mark-up on wages paid or a stated bill rate for hours worked. The majority
of our customers are billed a rate per hour worked which includes wages and benefits. We generally bill our customers
either in advance, weekly, bi-weekly or monthly.

Our revenue growth in the year ended December 31, 2020 over the corresponding period was driven by
acquisitions, as well as organic revenue growth related to bill-rate improvements. Our organic revenue growth is
driven primarily by our ability to maintain strong customer retention rates and to attract new customers. Our contract
security officer revenues and high retention rates are dependent on our ability to attract and retain high-quality,
qualified employees. Our wage rates are generally above market averages, and we provide our security officers with
benefits at a higher level than many of our competitors. In addition, we engage in extensive candidate screening,
training and development, which supports employee retention. We believe our employee retention rate compares
favorably to the average retention rates in our industry. In turn, this has allowed us to realize higher than average
customer bill rates.

In addition to our security officer services, we provide security system, janitorial and other ancillary services
for our customers. Our security systems solutions include consulting, design and engineering, installation, and event
and repair services for security systems. These revenue streams represented approximately 6% of our total revenue
during the year ended December 31, 2020.

**Direct Expenses**

Direct expenses are comprised primarily of direct labor, payroll taxes, medical and life insurance benefits,
workers’ compensation costs, general liability, employment practices liability and automobile insurance costs, and
subcontract labor and other direct expenses. We classify all of our security officer wages and our account manager
compensation and payroll-related expenses as direct expenses. Compensation paid includes regular pay, overtime pay
for hourly personnel, bonus, vacation, training, holiday and sick time. The total hours paid normally exceeds total
hours billed principally due to unbillable overtime and certain other unbillable costs. We believe that we have higher
wage and benefit costs than other companies in our industry, due to our focus on attracting, developing and retaining
a highly qualified workforce.


-----

General wage inflation, payroll tax rate and related taxable wage threshold changes, and insurance premiums
and related claim costs are the primary drivers that affect the major components of direct expenses. Traditionally, we
have been able to pass increased costs in these areas on to our customers.

Our payroll tax expenses historically are higher in the first half of the year because a significant number of
employees do not reach their taxable wage limits for employer related federal and state unemployment taxes until the
second half of the year.

Medical benefit costs for the majority of our workforce consist of premium-based insurance costs.
Conversely, for administrative employees and security officers not subject to premium-based coverage, we are selfinsured and subject to self-insured retention limits. See “Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates” for further
discussion.

**Key Factors Affecting Allied Universal’s Performance**

We believe the following trends and factors have an important impact on our financial performance:

  - Continued growth in the security market: Due to increased occurrences of adverse safety and security events
affecting the general public, continued wage growth, and increased outsourced services penetration, we
continue to see growth in the total size of the security market in the United States and globally. As a marketleading provider of security services and technology solutions, overall industry growth is a factor driving our
business. As such, our financial results are significantly affected by overall industry growth.

  - Increasing pressure on customer pricing combined with a competitive labor market: The security market is
intensely competitive as there are relatively low barriers to entry. We compete directly with companies that
are local, regional, national and international in scope. As more customers select service providers through
competitive bid processes intended to procure quality services at lower prices, our customer retention may
be affected as new market competitors may be willing to provide services at lower prices and margins. In
addition, we face pressure to increase compensation and benefits for employees as we compete with other
companies for the same workforce. Our ability to retain customers is dependent on our ability to hire, train
and retain employees at scale while efficiently deploying our workforce to efficiently meet our customers’
security service needs.

  - Our ability to deliver comprehensive, integrated security solutions and expand the use of technology:
Increasingly, our clients are asking us for more complex technology solutions and security operations
services. As such, we believe that our success will be based on our ability to tailor specific, innovative
solutions to meet the changing needs of our clients.

  - Our sales performance and ability to execute on strategy: The number of clients that we add in a given period
impacts our longer-term revenue. We are focused on attracting new clients, and expanding our service
offerings at existing clients. Furthermore, our ability to continue to pass along rate increases to our customers
will protect our margins but in part, could be offset by reduced hours.

  - Our continued ability to acquire and integrate accretive targets: Since 2007, and as of December 31, 2020,
we have acquired 73 businesses. Our acquisition process allows us to integrate targets, while minimizing
client disruption. Furthermore, we view expansion into international and adjacent markets to be an
opportunity driving future growth.

**Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates**

Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based upon our
consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with GAAP. The preparation of the
financial statements requires management to make certain estimates, judgments and assumptions that affect the
reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial
statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. We base these estimates,
judgments and assumptions on historical experience and on other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the
circumstances. Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions. We believe
the following critical policies affect our more significant estimates and assumptions used in the preparation of our
consolidated financial statements.

**Business Combinations**

The cost of an acquired business is assigned to the tangible and intangible assets purchased and liabilities
assumed on the basis of their fair values at the date of acquisition. The determination of fair values of assets acquired
and liabilities assumed requires us to make estimates and use valuation techniques when a market value is not readily
available. Any excess of purchase price over the fair value of tangible and intangible assets acquired and obligations
assumed is allocated to goodwill. Goodwill typically represents the value paid for the assembled workforce and
enhancement of our service offerings.

As part of certain completed acquisitions, we may agree to pay cash to the sellers based upon achievement
of certain targets after the acquisition date. The fair values of these contingent consideration arrangements are
estimated using a probability weighted income approach. We evaluate the fair value of the contingent consideration
throughout the year and every reporting period. Changes in the fair value during the measurement period that pertain


-----

to facts and circumstances that existed as of the acquisition date are recorded as measurement period adjustments to
goodwill. Changes in the fair value resulting from events that occurred after the acquisition date are recorded as a gain
or loss on changes in fair value of the contingent purchase consideration in the consolidated statements of operations.

**Allowance for Doubtful Accounts Reserve**

We offer our products and services to public and private sector customers. The financial condition of our
customers is affected by changes in general economic conditions as well as by other economic pressures in the markets
in which our customers operate. We believe that the credit risk associated with our trade accounts receivable is
mitigated by the fact that our customer base is diverse and geographically dispersed within North America. We do not
require collateral for trade receivables; however, we monitor our customer relationships in order to minimize our credit
risk.

We perform ongoing credit evaluations of our customers’ financial condition and maintain an allowance for
doubtful accounts based on a culmination of factors. These factors include: (1) customer creditworthiness, (2) aging
of accounts receivable, (3) past transaction history with the customer, (4) current economic industry trends and
(5) changes in customer payment terms. If the financial condition of our customers were to deteriorate, adversely
affecting their ability to make payments, we would provide additional allowances. Changes in these factors, among
others, may lead to adjustments in our allowance for doubtful accounts. The calculation of the allowance requires
judgment as to the impact of those and other factors on the ultimate realization of trade accounts receivable. We writeoff trade accounts receivable to the allowance for doubtful accounts when we determine collection is unlikely and we
have ceased our collection efforts.

**Long-lived Asset Impairment**

Long-lived assets include identifiable intangibles with finite lives (such as customer relationships) and
property and equipment. We review our long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances
indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. Such events and circumstances include,
among other factors:

  - current period operating losses or negative cash flow combined with a history of similar losses or forecasts
indicating continuing losses associated with the use of an asset,

  - significant decreases in the market value of an asset,

  - technological developments resulting in obsolescence,

  - significant changes in demand for our services in competition and competitive practices, or

  - significant negative changes in the business climate, industry or economic conditions.

Recoverability of our long-lived assets is determined based upon the expected undiscounted future net cash
flows from the operations to which the assets relate, utilizing our best estimates, appropriate assumptions, and
projections at the time of review. If the carrying value is determined not to be recoverable from future operating cash
flows, the asset is deemed impaired, and an impairment loss would be recognized to the extent the carrying value
exceeded the estimated fair market value of the asset.

**Goodwill and Indefinite-lived Intangible Asset Impairment**

Goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives are not amortized; rather, they are tested for impairment
annually as of October 1. For goodwill, which we have determined is a single reporting unit, we may conduct an
assessment of qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit
is less than its carrying amount. In a qualitative assessment, we would consider the macroeconomic conditions,
including any deterioration of general conditions and industry and market conditions, including any deterioration in
the environment where the reporting unit operates, increased competition, changes in the products/services and
regulatory and political developments, cost of doing business, overall financial performance, including any declining
cash flows and performance in relation to planned revenues and earnings in past periods, other relevant reporting unit
specific facts, such as changes in management or key personnel or pending litigation, and events affecting the reporting
unit, including changes in the carrying value of net assets. If we determine that it is more likely than not that the fair


-----

value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying value, then we would perform the quantitative goodwill impairment
test as required. If we determine that it is not more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than
the carrying value, then no further testing is required. If the carrying amount exceeds the fair value then we would
record an impairment loss in an amount equal to that excess, limited to the total amount of goodwill allocated to the
reporting unit. We estimate the fair value of our reporting unit based on a combination of significant observable and
unobservable inputs, including estimates of future operating performance. Changes in market conditions, among other
factors, may have an impact on these estimates.

For our indefinite-lived trade names, we may also conduct an assessment of qualitative factors to determine
whether or not it is more likely than not that the fair value of the assets is less than their carrying value. If we determine
that it is more likely than not that the fair value of the trade names is less than their carrying value, we estimate the
fair value of our indefinite-lived trade names using the relief from royalty method. The relief from royalty method
measures the discounted cash flow savings realized from owning such intangible assets and not having to pay a royalty
for their use. Impairment would then be recognized for the difference between the determined fair value and their
carrying value, if applicable.

**Insurance Reserves**

We maintain insurance coverage, subject to certain self-insured retention limits, for workers’ compensation,
general liability, employment practices liability, automobile liability and healthcare claims. Medical benefit costs for
the majority of our workforce are premium-based. Costs associated with the premium-based plans equal the actual
premiums paid and premiums can fluctuate. Conversely, for administrative employees and security officers not subject
to premium-based coverage, we are self-insured and subject to self-insured retention limits.

We record a reserve if we believe it is probable that we have incurred a liability and we can reasonably
estimate the amount of the loss. We provide a reserve for all known claims and those claims that we believe have been
incurred but not reported as of the balance sheet date based on our estimate of the ultimate cost of the claims. Our
estimates of the ultimate cost of claims are derived from the level of our insurance coverages, our retained risk of loss,
third-party actuarial analyses and management’s judgment. We review these estimates on a quarterly basis subject to
information then currently available to assess their adequacy and the propriety of disclosure. We adjust the reserves,
if needed, based on the results of our review. Assessing the adequacy of these reserves is highly subjective and requires
judgments about future events. The amount of the actual loss may differ significantly from these estimates.

In the normal course of operations, various legal claims are filed against the Company for which we maintain
insurance coverage. We have reserved for these claims based on insurance coverage, the risk of loss retained by the
Company and management’s judgment. We do not expect the ultimate outcome of any of these actions to have a
material adverse effect on our consolidated financial position, results of operations, or cash flows.

**Equity Unit-Based Compensation Plans**

Equity unit-based compensation costs are measured at the grant date based on the fair value of the equity
award using an appropriate option-pricing method and are recognized in the statements of operations over the period
during which an employee is required to provide service in exchange for the award. This expense is presented as a
separate line item under operating costs and expenses in the consolidated statements of operations.

We use an independent valuation advisor to assist with determining the fair value of the equity awards used
for calculating equity unit-based compensation. We consider both the historical volatility of our peer group’s stock
prices, as well as implied volatilities from exchange-traded options on our peer group’s equity units, as applicable.
The expected term used represents the period that the equity units are expected to be outstanding and is determined
using the simplified method. The assumptions used in calculating the fair value of equity unit-based awards represent
management’s best estimates, but these estimates involve inherent uncertainties and the application of management’s
judgment. As a result, if factors change and different assumptions were used, equity unit-based compensation could
materially differ in the future. In addition, we are required to estimate the expected forfeiture rate as well as
achievement of any performance metric specified within the award, and only recognize expense for those units
expected to vest. If the actual forfeiture rate or expected achievement of the performance metric is materially different


-----

from its estimate, the equity unit-based compensation expense could be significantly different from what we have
recorded in the current period.

**Income Taxes**

Within our financial reporting structure there are legal entities treated as partnerships and C-corporations that
are both consolidated and treated separately for federal and state income tax reporting purposes. The legal entities that
are treated as partnerships for federal and state income tax purposes pass their taxable income or loss through to the
members who report their share of the income or loss which has been allocated to them under the respective
membership agreements. The membership agreements have provisions requiring the distribution of funds to the
members in amounts sufficient for the members to satisfy their federal, state, and local tax obligations with respect to
their share of our income, subject to board approval.

The legal entities that are treated as C-corporations calculate an income tax provision or benefit for the current
income taxes and deferred income tax assets and liabilities as a result of differences between the accounting and tax
treatment of items related to these entities. Where, based on the weight of available evidence, it is more likely than
not that some amount of a recorded deferred tax asset will not be realized, a valuation allowance is established for the
amount sufficient to reduce that deferred tax asset to an amount that is more likely than not to be realized.

We file U.S. federal, state, and foreign tax returns. Tax returns for years beginning in 2017 are subject to
audit by the Internal Revenue Service and various tax authorities. While we have accrued for amounts we believe are
in accordance with the accounting standard, the final outcome with a tax authority may result in a tax liability that is
more or less than that reflected in the consolidated financial statements. Furthermore, we may later decide to challenge
any assessments, if made, and may exercise our right to appeal. Uncertain tax positions are reviewed annually with
guidance provided in ASC Topic 740, Income Taxes for recognizing and measuring tax positions taken or expected
to be taken in a tax return that directly or indirectly affect amounts reported in financial statements. ASC Topic 740
also provides accounting guidance for the related income tax effects of individual tax positions that do not meet the
recognition thresholds required in order for any part of the benefit of that tax position to be recognized in an entity’s
financial statements.

Outstanding balances under the Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility, Existing Delayed Draw Term Loan
Facility and Existing Revolving Credit Facility accrue interest equal to, at our option: (a) LIBOR plus 4.25% or (b) at
the bank’s prime rate plus between 2.75% and 3.25% based on a first lien leverage calculation. Amounts drawn on
the ABL Credit Facility accrue interest equal to, at our option: (a) LIBOR plus between 1.25% and 1.75% or (b) at
the bank’s prime rate, plus between 0.25% and 0.75%. We incur a fixed 4.25% fee on all outstanding issued letters of
credit (“LoCs”) pledged against the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and incur a 1.25% or 1.50% fee on all
outstanding issued LoCs pledged against the ABL Credit Facility. In addition, we incur a fixed 0.125% issuer fee on
all outstanding LoCs pledged against the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and ABL Credit Facility.

Outstanding balances under the Existing 2026 Secured Notes accrue interest at an annual rate of 6.625%.
Outstanding balances under the Existing 2027 Unsecured Notes accrue interest at an annual rate of 9.750%.

Principal on the Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility and Existing Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility is
payable in equal quarterly installments of 0.25% of the original aggregate principal amounts, with the remaining

**BUSINESS**

**Our Company**

**Business Overview**

Allied Universal is North America’s leading security and facility services provider. With over 250,000
security professionals and offices located throughout the United States as well as internationally (Canada, Mexico,
and the United Kingdom), Allied Universal serves approximately 14,800 clients and is responsible for protecting more
than 50,000 client sites covering multiple specialty sectors such as higher education, healthcare, retail, commercial
real estate, government, and corporate campuses, including a significant portion of the Fortune 500 companies. Allied
Universal’s services span manned guarding, innovative technology systems, risk and consulting, janitorial and staffing
services, integration services, and digital solutions and remote monitoring.

We are responsible for providing “best-in-class” security services that allow clients to completely outsource
the recruiting, screening, hiring, training, uniforming, scheduling and supervision of security officers. Our security
officers work on-location at customer sites and are responsible for observing, detecting, deterring and reporting and
responding to perceived, potential or actual security threats. We also provide specialized security services such as
vehicle patrol, visitor management, K-9 security services, top security facility cleared security professionals, and joint
security programs. We have an operational presence in all 50 US states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico and
have a growing presence in Canada, Latin America, and the United Kingdom.

In addition to providing manned guarding services, we provide comprehensive technology solutions to our
customers, including video surveillance, CCTV picture capture and monitoring, robot patrolling, GPS-based patrol
and reporting, management of access control points and centralized security operations. We also offer systems
integration services to design, install and service fully integrated technology-based monitoring systems, along with
digital solutions and remote monitoring through our MaRC. We are able to leverage our large manned guarding
customer base and service platform to cross-sell these additional system integration services. Finally, we offer a range
of ancillary services, including temporary and permanent staffing, event staffing and security, janitorial services, and
consulting and investigation solutions.

Allied Universal was formed in August 2016 through the combination of AlliedBarton and Universal, which
brought together two of the leading providers in the security services industry. AlliedBarton, founded in 1957, and
Universal, founded in 1965, were leaders in the industry in customer service, organic growth, customer and employee
retention, accretive M&A, and had a highly complementary and diverse set of blue chip customers. The combined
company became the largest provider of security officer services in North America and has continued to grow since,
both organically and through M&A. In the fourth quarter of 2018, Allied Universal acquired U.S. Security Associates
Holdings, Inc., a leading North American provider of security solutions, including manned security, consulting,
investigations, and disaster and emergency response services. Since 2007, the company has successfully executed 72
acquisitions, including small and large tuck-ins. In the fourth quarter of 2019, Allied announced the acquisition of
SOS Security which brought a complementary approach and further scale to Allied Universal. As of 2020, Allied
Universal has an estimated 31% share of the highly fragmented outsourced manned guarding security services market
in the United States, with a track record of growth driven both organically and through acquisitions.

For the year ended December 31, 2020, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, we had
Pro Forma Combined Adjusted Revenues of $18,357.1 million and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA of
$1,955.9 million, respectively. See “—Summary Historical Consolidated and Pro Forma Combined Financial
Information” for a reconciliation of Pro Forma Combined Adjusted Revenues and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted
EBITDA to revenues and net income (loss), the most directly comparable GAAP and/or IFRS measures.

**G4S Acquisition**

On December 8, 2020, the governing boards of Allied Universal and of G4S announced that they had reached
agreement on the terms of a recommended cash offer, to be made by Allied Bidco, a newly incorporated entity that is
indirectly controlled by Allied Universal, to acquire the entire issued and to be issued share capital of G4S, with G4S’


-----

directors recommending Allied Universal’s offer of 245 pence per share, representing a purchase price of
approximately £3.8 billion and total enterprise value of approximately £5.4 billion (the G4S Offer). On March 16,
2021, we announced the offer becoming unconditional as to acceptances, having received valid acceptances
representing approximately 79% of total G4S shares. On April 6, 2021, the G4S Offer became wholly unconditional,
and we completed the G4S Acquisition.

**G4S Overview**

G4S is a leading global security company, specializing in the provision of security services and solutions to
customers around the world. G4S’s roots can be traced back approximately 120 years ago to 1901, when the guarding
company Kjøbenhavn Frederiksberg Nattevagt was established in Denmark. Since then, G4S has expanded both
organically and through acquisitions, culminating in the merger of Securicor and Group 4 Falck to create G4S in 2004.
G4S is active in 90 countries across the globe, has more than 490,000 security professionals, and purchases goods and
services from approximately 40,000 suppliers. G4S has security integration capabilities in more than 40 key markets
and more than 13,000 monitored end points with key markets across the Americas, Africa, Asia and EMEA. Key
services include system design, integration & maintenance, manned & mobile guarding, monitoring & response,
consultancy & risk management, analytics, equipment and software. G4S provides its services to a broad range of
customers across various types of sites, including Fortune 500 companies, construction sites and manufacturing
facilities, hospital campuses and healthcare facilities, oil, gas, energy and other regulated facilities, financial
institutions and banking centers, college and university campuses, courthouses and government buildings, law
enforcement support including detainee processing and transport, and gated and residential communities.

The G4S business model starts with anticipating customer needs through detailed risk assessments. G4S is
investing in the resources, skills and capabilities needed to market, design, build, operate and maintain technologyenabled Integrated Security solutions. Through its Secure Solutions segment, G4S is a global market leader in security,
providing both traditional manned-guarding and technology-enabled security solutions in addition to consultancy
services and analytics to its customers. G4S uses its expertise, service delivery and integration alongside its geographic
scale to differentiate the business to customers, drive outsourcing and enhance the value of traditional security services
through greater use of technology. G4S officers are tailored for the specific need of each client, including the
following: custom protection officers who meet stringent experience and training requirements and are prepared to
step into high profile locations; upscale security officers who perform security patrols of designated areas on foot or
in a vehicle; lobby ambassadors who present a professional and courteous appearance while also possessing customer
service skills and focus and bank protection officers who provide visible deterrence of criminal activity at entrances
of financial institutions and banking centers. Currently, technology-enabled security services represent approximately
45% of Secure Solutions revenue. G4S is focused on pivoting from manned guarding to “predictive” security services
with consulting, technology, people and data analytics to continue margin expansion going forward.

G4S’s Cash Solutions segment is comprised of the Retail Technology Solutions and Conventional Cash
divisions. On February 26, 2020, G4S announced it agreed to sell the majority of its Conventional Cash businesses to
Brink’s for cash consideration of £666 million, allowing it to focus on the growth of its core integrated security
solutions business and further develop the rapidly growing Retail Technology Solutions business. Retail Technology
Solutions provides unique, value-add cash management solutions to clients and goes to market through the brands
Retail Cash Solutions, CASH360, Desposita, G4SPay, and South Africa-Deposits. G4S technologies offer a breadth
of solutions to clients including automated cash management and reconciliation and unique forecasting tools for retail
cash operations. Conventional Cash services include armored cash transportation, typically facilitated between cash
centers and customer outlets, as well as counterfeit detection, cash redistribution to banks and ATMs, ATM
management, including cash forecasting, replenishment, reconciliation and maintenance, counting and secure
international transportation of cash and valuables including, but not limited to, currency, gems and precious metals.

G4S’s Consulting Services segment helps clients manage and react to risks, such as risks associated with
crime, terrorism and entering into new markets, by providing remote site services and facilities management capability
in low infrastructure, conflict afflicted and hostile environments. Such services include security, aviation security,
facilities management, life support, remote logistics and fleet management, and training and capacity building
services. Additionally, the G4S Ordnance Management teams help clear explosives and other forms of ordnance from
sites that were once occupied by ISIS.


-----

G4S’s Care & Justice Services segment, which is concentrated in the United Kingdom and Australia, provides
custody and detention, rehabilitation, education, employment, electronic monitoring, immigration and borders, police
back office support, secure healthcare and non-urgent patient transport services to central and local governments and
their agencies, regulatory bodies, UK police forces and the private sector. The Care & Justice Services segment also
provides critical primary and forensic healthcare services for the public and private sectors and provides healthcare
services within police custody suites and other secure environments, caring for detainee health needs and supporting
the collection of forensic samples.

Further, as a responsible employer, G4S’s priorities embrace sustainable investment to promote the health
and safety of employees, as reflected in the improvement in G4S’s health and safety performance over the past seven
years. For example, during 2020, 15 G4S employees lost their lives in the course of carrying out their duties, as
compared with 20 fatalities in 2019, which was significantly lower than levels experienced in earlier years, reflecting
the benefits of G4S’s health and safety programs. G4S continues to reduce its employee injury rate, and lost time
injury rates also improved, falling from 5.7 per 1,000 employees in 2019 to 4.6 in 2020. In addition, during 2020, G4S
launched a mental health awareness campaign entitled Ready to Work, recognizing that communities have been under
additional stress during the year with the impact of COVID-19, which program will continue into 2021.

In terms of risk mitigation, G4S believes that behaving with integrity and respect is key to G4S’ core values,
forming an integral part of the G4S’s strategy and an essential foundation on which G4S carries out its business. To
that end, in 2020, G4S reviewed and relaunched a number of its ethics and social responsibility policies. G4S’s new
Ethics Code sets out the ethical standards which apply to all G4S businesses and employees. This was launched early
in 2021, supported by an extensive communications, training and engagement program. In addition, G4S has also
updated its whistleblowing policy, anti-bribery & corruption framework and its human rights policy and
accompanying guidance. G4S has also refreshed its training program on ABC. To ensure the training is effective and
reaches those who need it, in addition to all new employees, all managers and staff with responsibility for making any
financial decisions and for controlling assets have been prioritized to undertake the new ABC training and to repeat it
annually.

Given the significant re-shaping of G4S’s business portfolio in recent years, we believe that the G4S is now
positioned to develop an enhanced service mix with a growing proportion of higher value Integrated Security services.
The combined benefits of the G4S strategy, strong execution, emphasis on employee health and safety, continued
focus on risk mitigation and rapid response to COVID-19 are reflected in G4S’s underlying results for the year ended
December 31, 2020. Please see “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information of G4S” and
the audited financial statements of G4S and accompanying notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering circular.

**Strategic Rationale**

**Enhances the combined company’s geographic coverage and capabilities to serve customers, especially in the**
**core North America market, which represents approximately 70% of pro forma combined revenues**

We believe the G4S acquisition is a strategically and financially compelling transaction that will expand our
geographic footprint, enhance our scale, diversify our products and services offering, increase market position and
provide new growth channels in untapped regions and end-markets. The acquisition of G4S provides Allied Universal
with a unique opportunity to acquire a well-established integrated security services company with a globally
recognized security services brand, and platform to increase the combined company’s top line sales and profitability.
Allied Universal and G4S are two of the top five global companies in the highly fragmented security services industry
based on revenue. Together, we will be a global leading company in the security services.

The transaction enhances the combined company’s geographic coverage and capabilities to serve customers,
especially in the core North America market, which represents approximately 70% of pro forma combined revenues.
Allied Universal has a strong footprint in North America with a presence in all 50 states, and the merger with G4S
creates unparalleled scale and increases density, with footprint overlap allowing the combined company to take a bestof approach to servicing clients in the various regions. Based on revenue generation, we rank number one in Manned
Guarding and Retail Technology solutions and number three in Security Technology in North America. We provide
a comprehensive, diverse product offering with value-added services and world-class quality to our end-customers.
We believe our increased scale in multiple regions and the breadth of our services will make our services more


-----

attractive to our customers. Both Allied Universal and G4S provide diversified solutions in addition to traditional
manned guarding services. The Allied Universal and G4S transaction creates a fully integrated security business with
the ability to address customers’ evolving security needs in an increasingly evolving and fast-changing world with
increased demand.

**Increases diversification across end-markets, customers and geographies**

While Allied Universal has historically focused more on the North American region, the acquisition of G4S
enables Allied Universal to significantly increase its global footprint and diversify its base to operating in over 90
countries. The combination with G4S establishes Allied Universal as a global security services leader with unmatched
scale and expertise in providing quality security services across a range of geographies. The combination of Allied
Universal’s and G4S’s solutions and significant manned-guarding businesses will create a global one-stop-shop for
customers and a business ideally positioned to lead the industry shift from traditional security officer and patrol
services towards services that integrate technology solutions with manned security services. See “—Industry
Overview—Security Services Technology.” Allied Universal’s decades of experience in risk advisory and consulting,
investigations, executive protection and emergency response will complement G4S’s corporate risk services to provide
end-to-end security solutions. With appropriate support, capital and assistance from Allied Universal, G4S would be
able to concentrate on addressing the ongoing industry shift towards electronic and technology-based services.

**Strengthens platform with blue chip customer base**

The combination of Allied Universal and G4S will create a world-leading integrated security business
providing services to an extensive portfolio of blue-chip clients across the public and private sectors. We sell to a
diversified customer base and end-markets in various verticals, including commercial real estate, retail and malls,
government, healthcare, tech and media, manufacturing and industrial, financial institution, chemical and
petrochemical, and aerospace and defense. We are the trusted provider to premium accounts for clients with greater
than $5 million annual revenue across multiple regions and a central point of contact for purchasing security services.
Our leading global scale helps promote trust and confidence among our sophisticated customers and serves as a
significant differentiator versus regional competitors. The combination expands Allied Universal’s base of long
tenured blue chip customers globally and uniquely positions the combined company to serve customers seeking
integrated security solutions providers of scale. Allied Universal has had annual revenue retention of over 90% for the
past 5 years and has minimal customer concentration with top five customers representing less than 5% of revenues.
Doing business and negotiating long-term contracts through a centralized procurement division drives strong valueadded partnerships underpinned by highly sticky relationships, which increase the switching costs for our customers.

**Acquisition adds density and expertise to North America technology business**

The combined group will increase Allied Universal’s reach and depth of services, enhancing our leadership
position and allowing us to expand internationally on current domestic accounts. While Allied Universal has an
established customer base with significant density in traditional manned-guarding services, G4S will contribute to our
operational scale in Retail Cash solutions and Retail Technology solutions, which have grown since launching in 2015.
We see this as a new services platform, especially in our security technology services that we can cross-sell with North
American customers and improve Allied Universal’s services coverage. The expansion of Allied Universal’s
technology services platform capabilities will enable the combined company to offer superior client service, with
greater breadth, accountability, improved efficiency and cost savings. We have competitive advantages through strong
trajectory relative to competitors and potential disruptors and we transfer our knowledge and experience in the United
States to deploy our abilities to compete in adjacent markets.

**Meaningful cost synergy opportunity**

We intend to deploy operational and strategic best practices across Allied Universal and G4S to drive
additional growth, enable cross-selling capabilities, enhance operational performance and increase free cash flow
conversion. We estimate that the combination will unlock approximately $155 million in targeted annual cost savings
once G4S is fully integrated and our cost savings initiatives have been fully implemented. Allied Universal has a
strong track record of successful acquisition integration, including synergy realization. We anticipate that our
disciplined management of fixed and variable operating expenses, revenue and financing synergies, as well as


-----

corporate overhead and headcount rationalization will primarily drive cost synergies. Historically, we have made a
significant number of acquisitions and we have well-developed systems and processes throughout our organization to
support integration efforts, resulting in more efficient synergy realization and helping drive overall margin
improvement.

The overlapping business functions in North America provide a significant opportunity for real estate and
personnel rationalization. Due to overlapping operations, we expect significant synergies in the following areas in the
North America region: general and administrative expenses, duplicative service contracts, insurance, and facilities
expense. Additionally, we will be able to eliminate any expenses in functional support areas that support G4S’s status
as a public listed company. Further, we believe opportunities exist to increase operating leverage through
diversification across investment in capabilities, such as additional training and technology deployments.

**Industry Overview**

**Market Overview**

The global contract security services market is large, has been stable and is expected to continue its consistent
growth supported by a number of favorable trends. The US security services market was estimated to generate
approximately $66 billion in revenue in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 4% to 5% CAGR from 2021 to 2025. The
US security services market for outsourced manned guarding generated over $28 billion in revenue in 2020 and grew
at a 4.3% CAGR from 2017 to 2020. The security technology market in the US is also large, with revenues estimated
to be approximately $17 billion in 2020, and grew slightly quicker than the manned guarding segment, at a CAGR of
approximately 8% from 2017 to 2020. The market was estimated to be comprised of approximately 42% manned
guarding and 25% security technology. Internationally, the security services market for manned guarding grew to $34
billion in revenue in 2020 and is expected to reach approximately $40 billion in revenue in 2025, representing an
estimated compound annual growth rate of 5% from 2021 to 2025.

A heightened focus on security, both in the United States and globally, has been driven by high profile gun
violence, domestic terrorism events, a rise in workplace incidents and both peaceful and violent protest events, which
have led to increased spending on security. Our service offerings represent an important first line of defense against
potential security threats. Meanwhile, mega trends occurring around the world and positive growth tailwinds in the
distribution, manufacturing, healthcare and education sectors also support demand for increasing security. In addition,
organizations continue to outsource their security services primarily to alleviate administrative burdens and achieve
cost savings, while the compelling value proposition delivered through scale, broad service offerings and robust
technological infrastructure drive them to shift to highly professionalized providers.

Given the high-risk exposure of inadequate security, we believe that customers make purchasing decisions
based on service quality, reliability, and reputation, rather than price alone. It has been our experience that customers
seek out and maintain long-term relationships with quality providers. For example, industry switching rates have
historically been between 10% to 15% on average annually, and customer retention rates are higher for large customers
served under national contracts, according to a third party consulting study. Meanwhile, Allied Universal, as a scale
provider, experienced below average annual customer switching rates of between 5% to 10%.

We believe the industry’s stability in various economic cycles is underpinned by the recession-resistant
nature of security services, resulting in limited cyclicality and customer churn. Over a ten-year period, industry growth
has been consistent, and historically recession-resistant, experiencing only one year of flat-to-slightly declining
growth. The impact of economic downturns on labor markets, which includes higher employee retention, and
subsequently lower unbilled overtime, recruiting and training costs, historically have led to EBITDA margin
expansion, which has historically been sustained during a return to economic expansion. Our experience during 2020
demonstrates the resiliency of our business model. Despite lockdowns and office closures during the COVID
pandemic, security services remained an essential part of real estate management and asset protection. During this
period, we also experienced a temporary shift in demand from security services in connection with retail, travel and
leisure to grocery and other essential businesses. We also experienced an increase in demand for higher value-add
services such as temperature screening. During the summer of 2020, protests and other civil events drove demand for
our manned guarding services, providing further diversification and resiliency against office closings.

**Market Drivers**

The US security services and security technology integration and manned guarding market is expected to
grow at a CAGR of approximately 5% from 2021 through 2025. Several positive trends support this growth, including:
(i) baseline expansion from building stock growth, guard penetration in existing buildings, and wage rate growth
which is passed on through the mark-up model used to price security services; (ii) secular demand growth due to
heightened focus on security driven by increased acts of violence and media coverage, increasing regulatory and
insurance scrutiny; and (iii) increased outsourcing rate for security services. Furthermore, there is a trend toward the
centralization of security programs and integration of manned guarding with technology solutions, both of which favor
best-in-class national providers. As the national player with vertical markets expertise and differentiated integrated
security and technology solutions, we are well-positioned to benefit from favorable industry tailwinds.

Globally, demand for security services has also increased steadily and is expected to grow at a CAGR of
4.9% between 2020 and 2024. Demand is driven by similar factors as in the United States as well as elevated safety
and security risks and concerns driven by geopolitical events such as refuge crises, increased wealth driven by
urbanization, global GDP growth, rising labor costs supporting demand for higher-value, technology-enabled,
integrated security solutions and demand for higher-value service lines driven by more advanced technology
capabilities.

The COVID pandemic demonstrated the industry’s resilience as the global security services market continued
to experience growth despite lockdowns throughout much of the world.

**Base-Line Industry Growth**

Base-line industry growth is driven by underlying economic growth, growing wage rates and increasing
building stock, as each new building adds incremental demand for the security services industry. While building stock
growth provides strong underlying support for the security services market, it is not necessary to sustain growth within
our existing customer bases. A growing economy drives up overall wage rates, increases statutory minimum wages
and provides union increases, all which are typically passed on to customers through a stable mark-up. Increased wage
rates are expected to continue driving further expansion of the manned guarding market and increase revenue
generation from existing clients.

**Growing Demand for Security Services**

Security services remain critical and non-discretionary as customers overwhelmingly value the role of
security officers in deterring criminal activity and other incidents, all the while providing assurance against real or
perceived security threats. In cases of security incidents, customers value the officers’ ability to provide immediate
response. Technology can enhance and significantly improve security but we believe there is no substitute for the
physical presence of well-trained and dedicated security personnel who can respond to threats in real-time.


-----

The demand for security services continues to increase due to heightened security concerns stemming from
the ongoing threat of terrorism and high profile gun violence, large protest events, heightened importance of public
and workplace safety, refugee crises and the growing need to supplement services provided by the public sector.
Heightened media coverage of security lapses, growing costs of disruption, and stricter security requirements by
government institutions and private insurers have forced organizations to take greater responsibility for their own
security.

**Increased Outsourcing to Third-party Providers with National and Global Scale**

Currently, approximately 65% of manned security services in the United States are outsourced to professional
security services firms, and this outsourcing rate is expected to increase incrementally over time. The trend toward
outsourcing is expected to continue to drive growth in the industry due to the strong value proposition of contract
security service providers and non-core nature of security for the vast majority of companies.

Due to the growing complexity surrounding security-related issues and increased demand for vertical
segment expertise and customized guarding services, outsourcing security services to “best-in-class” providers
continues to be an attractive option for customers. Contract security services firms can offer customers improved
security, reduced non-core administrative burden, and competitive pricing through operating leverage, each of which
are compelling reasons supporting the trend toward outsourcing various business services. Outsourcing of non-core
functions has not only become a corporate best practice, but also a function of the public sector as governments look
to minimize cost. Outsourcing allows companies and governments to reduce labor costs and shift the administrative
burden of non-core functions to third-party vendors with more experience, operating leverage, and functional area
expertise.

As one of the few security and facility services providers with national and global scale, we believe the
combined Allied Universal and G4S business is well-positioned to benefit from the trend toward outsourcing security
services. For example, we are able to address customers’ increasingly complex security needs and their preference for
best-in-class providers with strong reputations and vertical markets expertise, rather than local providers. In addition,
as national customers increasingly seek to consolidate vendors, they build relationships with national partners that can
reliably and consistently serve them across multiple regions. Finally, the increased centralization of procurement
continues to drive the shift in customer decision-making from a local level to a multi-region and national level,
providing an opportunity for national providers to increase customer penetration.

**Security Services Technology**

Due to the importance of having security officers physically present to deter and quickly respond to incidents,
technology has been used primarily to enhance and better enable manned security services. Security services providers
such as Allied Universal and G4S continue to broaden their portfolio of services by combining value-added offerings
like access controls, ID verification, video monitoring, and communications systems with traditional security officer
and patrol services. Customers seek integration between manned guarding services and complementary technology
solutions in order to improve and reduce the complexity of their security operations. Existing customer relationships
create the ability to cross-sell services for the installation, integration and maintenance of physical technology systems
that augment manned guarding services. Integrated technology solutions enhance the value delivered to customers
and foster customer retention. They provide a recurring revenue model for providers, as they require one-time sales
and installations but involve regular system services and maintenance.

**Industry Consolidation**

Over the past eight years, the contract security services industry has consolidated through increased M&A
activity. Given the sustained fragmented nature of the industry, this trend is expected to continue in the near to
intermediate term. Reflecting the strong customer preference for national and increasingly global scale providers and
the operational and cost advantages of having local density, large contract security services providers continue to gain
market share. Together, Allied Universal and G4S will hold a leading market position and we expect to further growth
market share in the security services industry in the United States and globally in connection with the business
combination.

**Consistent, Recession-Resistant Industry**

The resilient nature of the security services market was demonstrated during the COVID pandemic, which
reaffirmed the essential nature of services provided by Allied Universal. Early in the pandemic, security professionals
were generally deemed essential by health authorities and continued to deliver security services to a range of
customers. Minor business disruptions at the onset of lockdowns led to a slight pullback in hours relative to the preCOVID period. Allied Universal has so far successfully managed the pandemic and performance has been highly
resilient both in top line growth and in margin expansion. Hours have since rebounded and even increased in some
regions as COVID-related restrictions have eased and economic activity continues to rebound, while increased
security concerns remain. Services have continued to expand as customers seek a partner to help implement and
execute new policies and procedures at guarded sites, in addition to offering additional services such as temperature
checks. An enhanced focus on innovative technology solutions drives further upside for security providers that offer
fully integrated solutions.

Allied Universal’s resilient top-line is driven by the contractual revenue streams with daily re-occurrence of
services, the critical nature of security to operations, and the low cost of security services relative to the high cost of
failure. The company typically benefits from rising wages as increases are passed on to clients, who generally expect
a 2% to 3% annual increase in billing rates, in-line with wage growth. Tightening labor markets result in stable
margins, while softer markets typically drive margin expansion as the increased supply of labor reduces the spread
between bill rates and employee pay rates.

**Stable and Predictable Financial Performance Coupled with Strong Free Cash Flow Generation**

_Consistent history of growth: Allied Universal has repeatedly demonstrated the ability to deliver growth,_
consistent and improving profitability, and strong cash flow. The nature of our customer contracts fosters a highly
visible financial model. Our recurring revenue base is supported by an above-average customer retention rate. To drive
revenue growth, both companies target new client wins, in particular the expansion of the premier customers portfolio
within Allied Universal, expanded scope of work and customer penetration with existing clients, added
complementary technology solutions, and consistent increases in price in line with wage rate growth and the delivery
of high- quality services. These organic growth drivers, coupled with our ability to execute upon accretive acquisition
opportunities, have contributed to strong revenue and Adjusted EBITDA growth. From 2005 to 2020, Allied
Universal’s standalone organic revenue CAGR was approximately 6% and from 2017 to 2020, Allied Universal
consistently grew the spread between bill rates and wage rates per hour by approximately 4.5%. Allied Universal’s
disciplined acquisition strategy combined with strong organic growth has allowed us to become the fastest growing
security services company in the industry while maintaining strong free cash flow generation. The combination
between Allied Universal and G4S is expected to drive further topline and profitability growth through significant
cross-selling and cost synergy opportunities.

_Highly-variable cost structure drives predictable margins: Bill rate, which is the price we charge to our_
customers per hour per security officer, is priced as a mark-up on security officer pay rates, which is the wage we pay
to security guards per hour. From 2016 to 2020, Allied Universal’s mark-up has remained constant at 1.48x. This
stable mark-up reflects the strong track record of passing on cost increases to clients and expanding margins. Our
ability to pass through labor costs and other variable expenses to our clients allows us to generate consistent
profitability and produce cash flows with low volatility. This consistency helps us maintain stable operating margins
and provides a baseline level of profitability from which further margin expansion can be achieved as we continue to
increase our operating leverage and scale, while reducing general and administrative expenses.

_Capital-light business model supports strong cash flow: Our minimal capital requirements and strong_
working capital management support our strong cash flow profile. Capital expenditures over the past three years were
approximately 1.8% of annual revenue on average, with cash capital expenditures representing about half of such
capital expenditures and the remaining portion funded through capital leases. We also have minimal and predictable
net working capital needs, which provides further visibility into free cash flow.
