**Highly Experienced Management Team**

We have a highly experienced and well-respected management team with a proven track record and
meaningful equity ownership. Management was responsible for developing and implementing the expansion strategy
that has led to industry-leading growth for the company. The team has a strong track record of continuously evolving
and growing the business through both organic and M&A strategies, and is experienced in integrating accretive
acquisitions. The team is committed to delivering continued growth, and has significant equity ownership in Allied
Universal. Outside of the executive management group, there is a deep bench of leadership and operational talent
throughout the organization given the selection of the best security specialists in connection with the merger of
AlliedBarton and Universal in 2016.

**Growth Strategy**

**Proven Ability to Win New Clients and Grow with Existing Clients**

Our underlying organic growth has historically been driven by hours growth attributable to (i) developing a
world-class sales and marketing organization, (ii) leveraging our competitive advantages to win new customers,
including premier customers, (iii) expanding customer penetration and leveraging cross-selling opportunities with
clients by delivering customized service offerings specific to customer needs, and (iv) maintaining steady underlying
customer retention rates in the 90% range in the long term, and pricing growth driven by passing on pay rate increases
to customers. In order to drive new customer wins for Allied Universal, our sales organization is structured by
salespeople focused on premier customers, salespeople focused on regional and local accounts, vertical market
specialists, and regional specialists. Our sales pipeline is robust, with the pipeline typically representing a multiple of
the annual new starts target. Premier customers sales efforts target customers with facilities in multiple locations
throughout the United States, who increasingly desire consistency of service, fewer points of contact and alignment
with a national partner providing a full suite of capabilities. As we have expanded our geographical footprint and
adapted sales and client service capabilities, we have become well-positioned to be the leading provider to premier
customers . With our existing customers, we seek to grow customer penetration by increasing the number of customer
sites served and thus the hours that our security officers cover, and adding on different types of security services. Our
organic growth is supported by underlying customer retention rates in the 90% range over the past 10 years. Given
the multi-year contractual nature of many of our large contracts, we have visibility over a significant portion of our


-----

revenue . We proactively manage contracts in advance of renewal, rebid or expiration. Finally, organic growth has
been driven by increasing pricing in line with security officer pay rate increases. We have demonstrated a history of
successfully increasing bill rates with pay rates, as evidenced by stable mark-up rate and increasing mark-up spread
over the long term.

We have grown our revenue at a CAGR of approximately 6% between 2005 and 2020. We believe we are
well-positioned to continue achieving measured growth by capitalizing on our strong reputation, enhanced operational
capabilities, vertical-specific service expertise and premier customers platform. In addition to increasing hours by
adding new accounts, benefiting from increased outsourcing, we will continue to leverage our significant experience
managing pricing dynamics to drive growth.

**Service Line Expansion**

The combination of Allied Universal and G4S is expected to generate meaningful cross-selling opportunities.
The combined comprehensive offering of security solutions across a global platform will allow the combined business
to serve as a one-stop-shop for existing customers served by the combined group, as well as new clients looking for a
global provider to serve their security needs. The expertise of each organization in serving specific end markets and
geographies will increase the overall reach and ability to serve global clients across a range of industries with a host
of complimentary services.

Our industry-leading manned guarding services provide a platform from which to continue offering
additional services. To date, we have utilized this platform to offer additional services, such as physical technology
systems, including video surveillance, CCTV picture capture and monitoring, robot patrolling, GPS based patrol and
reporting, online threat monitoring, and managing access control points and centralized security operation.
Additionally, we also offer integration services to design, install and service fully integrated technology-based
monitoring systems. Finally, we provide digital solutions and remote monitoring through MaRC.

Our acquisition of Securadyne in April 2019 further strengthened our ability to consult, design, deploy,
integrate and maintain electronic security systems for our customers. We believe the Securadyne acquisition provided
us with the footprint and scalable infrastructure that enables us to deliver complementary security integration services
to a significantly larger portion of the existing approximately 50,000 client sites where we provide manned guarding
services today.

In addition to system installation, maintenance, robots, and monitoring, we have integrated technology into
our manned guarding services and are in the process of deploying a custom IMS that provides real-time incident data
reporting and situational awareness information powered by artificial intelligence. The proprietary application,
HeliAUS, provides in-depth incident reporting, data collection, and predictive analytics, allowing managers and
clients to spot trends and react quickly, while improving workforce supervision and improving liability management.
The highly scalable platform is delivered to customers via a monthly subscription and is billed directly to users as a
supplement to manned guarding services.

Beyond our technology offerings, we intend to continue to grow our janitorial and staffing services, which
are a portfolio of offerings including cleaning services and a provider of skilled talent across a diverse set of industries
such as traditional janitorial functions as well as highly specialized cleaning services such as bio- hazard disposal, IT
room cleaning, and recycling programs.

**Proven Platform for Disciplined M&A**

We benefit from our significant experience in successfully integrating acquisitions while maintaining
relationships with both existing and acquired customers. The largely fragmented security services industry has
historically provided opportunities to supplement our strong organic growth with a disciplined acquisition strategy. A
large and fragmented international market, as well as relevant adjacent markets, provides additional opportunity for
targeted expansion. Our approach to acquisitions has been highly methodical and focused on scale-building and infill
acquisitions. Integration occurs quickly, generally within 30 days for a typical tuck-in acquisition, making for a
seamless transition for customers.


-----

Allied Universal has proven experience executing all types of transactions, including 72 small tuck-ins and
large transformational acquisitions since 2007. On average, these acquisitions were completed at credit accretive, midsingle digit multiples. In addition to many small and medium tuck-ins, we have a proven track record of successfully
executing and integrating transformative acquisitions, as evidenced by the combination of AlliedBarton and Universal
in August 2016, as well as the large tuck-in acquisition of USSA, formerly the fourth-largest manned guarding
provider in the United States in 2018. The combination of our smaller tuck-in acquisitions along with our ability to
acquire targets of scale, such as USSA, demonstrate our disciplined ability to take advantage of growth opportunities
as they become available.

We believe we are an “acquirer of choice” due to our strong reputation and track record and are the bestpositioned consolidator in a highly fragmented market. A significant portion of our past acquisitions have been
completed on a proprietary basis. Additionally, we estimate that over 40% of the outsourced manned guarding services
market in the United States is comprised of over 7,000 firms and roughly 60% of the security technology services
market is comprised of over 3,000 firms, providing a large opportunity set for further accretive consolidation. We
benefit from significant industrial logic from on-boarding sub-scale providers onto our scalable platform which drives
the ability to expand margins of acquired companies. We believe the combination of Allied Universal and G4S will
allow us to execute further our disciplined and well-demonstrated M&A playbook in key markets globally.

**Customers; Competition**

Through understanding our customers’ needs, we aim to offer value added, innovative, cost effective security
solutions and build enduring relationships. We engage with our customers through a variety of methods, including a
consultative approach to selling and bidding for contracts, proactive relationship management and a sharp focus on
customer service. Key areas of interests for customers include quality and price of service delivery, expertise and
innovation, health and safety and business ethics. However, the industries in which we operate are competitive. We
directly compete with companies that are national and international in scope. We also compete with smaller local and
regional companies that may have better knowledge of the local conditions in their regions, are better known locally
and are better able to gain customers in their regions. There are relatively low barriers to entry in the industries in
which we operate, and we have faced and expect to continue to face additional competition from new entrants. We
also face increased competition from technology companies as digital advancement develops, which may lead to
pricing pressure and service changes. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industries—The
industries in which we operate are intensely competitive and price-sensitive. If we cannot successfully compete with
new or existing providers of products and services similar to ours or enhance our existing products and services, our
results of operations and financial condition will be adversely affected.”

The United States contract security officer industry is highly competitive but fragmented. We also compete
with numerous smaller regional and local security service providers in the United States.

We believe that the principal competitive factors in the security service market are:

  - the quality of security officers, including length of service and tenure;

  - supervision, recruiting, selecting and training of security officers;

  - management quality and responsiveness;

  - the ability to handle multiple sites nationwide; and

  - price in relation to the quality of service.

Rapid technological advances, changing delivery models and evolving standards in computer hardware and
software development and communications infrastructure, changing and increasingly sophisticated customer needs
and frequent new product introductions and enhancements characterize the industries in which we compete.


-----

**Government Regulation**

We are subject to a large number of city, county and state, domestic and international laws and regulations
governing the provision of private security services. Relevant regulation for our operations and employees includes
such matters as consumer protection, fair trade, jurisdiction-specific security industry regulation (including with
respect to hardware requirements or operational requirements), data privacy, occupational health and safety, marketing
and competition law. Additionally, most states in the United States have laws, or legislation pending, requiring
qualification, training and registration of security officers, regulating the use of identification cards, badges and
uniforms and imposing minimum bond surety or insurance standards. In order to install a security system, we generally
must be licensed in the jurisdiction where we are installing the system. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our
Business and Industries—Our business operates in a regulated industry, and noncompliance with regulations could
materially restrict our operations and expose us to fines, penalties and other liabilities and negative consequences.”
Additionally, we generally must obtain operating certificates or permits for our security systems, and provide specified
levels of training to our employees at those centers.

Our international operations are subject to risks that are different from those we face in the United States and
subject us to complex and frequently changing laws and regulations, including differing labor laws and regulations
relating to the protection of certain information that we collect and maintain about our employees, clients and other
third parties. We operate under many complex and diverse regulatory frameworks, some of which have extraterritorial
reach and many where regulations change frequently. Among these laws are the U.K. Modern Slavery Act, the U.K.
Bribery Act, and the GDPR, which took effect in May 2018. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and
Industries—Our international business involves risks different from those we face in the United States that could have
an effect on our results of operations and financial condition.”

**Intellectual Property**

Allied Universal’s most material trademarks are “AU” and “ALLIED UNIVERSAL,” together with other
variants containing the term “ALLIED.” G4S’s most material trademarks are “G4S” and “Securing Your World.”
Neither Allied Universal nor G4S has had any significant difficulties registering any trademarks, nor are there any

**Employees**

On a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, we employ approximately 740,000 security
professionals and operate in more than 225 locations in all 50 US states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. As
of the date of this offering circular, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, approximately 26% of
our employees were unionized. We believe that our relationships with our employees are good, and we have not
experienced any work stoppages as a result of labor disputes.

With over 740,000 security professionals on a combined basis delivering critically important services across
every continent, employee and customer safety is of paramount importance to us. We have a continuing focus on
enhancing safety policies, standards and culture and our goal is zero harm. The nature of our work and the
environments in which we operate mean that security and safety present an operational and strategic risk to our
business and, from time to time, members of our workforce may be subject to injuries and fatalities. We believe that
setting the highest standards for health and safety across our industry helps to keep our security professionals safe and
builds employee loyalty and commitment to our combined company.

**Insurance**

We believe that we maintain all appropriate forms of insurance, including comprehensive general liability,
performance and crime bonding, professional liability, automobile coverage and excess and umbrella coverage.
Special coverage is sometimes added in response to unique customer requirements. We also maintain compliance with
all state workers’ compensation laws.


-----

We maintain insurance coverage, subject to certain self-insured retention limits, for workers’ compensation,
general liability, employment practices liability and healthcare claims (under employee medical benefit plans).
Medical benefit costs for the majority of our workforce are premium-based. Costs associated with the premium-based
plans equal the actual premiums paid. Conversely, for administrative employees and select security officers’ medical
coverages, we are self-insured and subject to self-insured retention limits.

**Legal Proceedings**

We are and, from time to time, may become party to regulatory proceedings or to litigation or subject to nonlitigated claims arising out of the normal operations of our businesses such as general liability and employment claims.
We cannot predict the timing or outcome of these claims and proceedings. For a description of certain ongoing and
past litigations, see “Risk Factors—Risk Related to Our Business—We are subject to risks from litigation or legal
proceedings, as well as tax audits, which could adversely affect our financial results and condition.”

Under the laws of many of the jurisdictions in which we operate, we may be held liable for the negligent acts
or misconduct of our agents or employees performed while on duty and in the course and scope of their employment.
We experience a significant volume of claims and litigation in the ordinary course of business asserting that we are
liable for damages as a result of the conduct of our employees or others. From time to time individuals bring personal
injury lawsuits against us seeking substantial damages based on alleged negligence or other theories of liability in our
provision of security services, including with respect to injuries not directly caused by, or within the control of, our
security officers. Under principles of common law, we generally can be held liable for wrongful acts or omissions to
act of our agents or employees during the course, and within the scope, of their agency or employment with us.

In addition, many of our customer contracts contain provisions whereby we are contractually obligated to
defend, indemnify and hold harmless our clients. These provisions vary from indemnification for our own negligence
and misconduct to providing indemnification for any claims related to our services regardless of our fault. In a limited
number of situations, we may also be contractually required to indemnify our customers in cases of their own
contributory negligence.

We are also subject to a significant number of wage and hour class actions and multi-plaintiff lawsuits, singleemployee lawsuits, Private Attorneys General Act claims and attorney demands, in addition to wage and hour
governmental audits.

We maintain insurance coverage, subject to certain self-insured retention limits, for workers’ compensation,
general liability, employment practices liability and healthcare claims (under employee medical benefit plans), which
we believe adequately insure us. We also seek to mitigate this risk exposure through indemnification or liability
limitations in our contracts, analysis of customer facilities and implementation of programs for employee screening,
training, supervision and safety and anonymous reporting by our employees. We believe that we have established
adequate reserves for litigation liabilities in our consolidated financial statements.

Currently, we are involved in certain legal and governmental matters, such as the DPA that G4S entered into
with the SFO in respect of the UK Care & Justice electronic monitoring contract investigation, inquiries that G4S
received from the BCA and DoJ in connection with G4S’s Belgian business, class action litigation relating to the Fair
Credit Reporting Act, claims under the Anti-Terrorism Act relating to alleged support provided by G4S to the Taliban


-----

in Afghanistan and certain claims in India relating to the India Provident Fund, as further described under “Risk
Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industries—The nature of our business exposes us to significant risks
related to legal proceedings, claims, governmental inquiries and investigations, and negative press and media
investigations that could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, and results of operations,” “Risk
Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industries—We are subject to risks from litigation or legal proceedings,
as well as tax audits, which could adversely affect our financial results and condition” and “Risk Factors—Risks
Related to Our Business and Industries—The security services we provide may subject us to liability for substantial
damages not covered by insurance.” We currently do not expect any of these matters nor any other legal or
governmental matters we are involved in to have a material adverse effect on our combined business, financial
condition, results of operations or cash flows, but we can provide no assurance on the future developments or outcomes
of any such arbitrations and/or legal proceedings discussed in this offering circular, including the G4S matters
discussed above. Exposure to litigation is inherent in our ongoing business and may materially harm our combined
business, financial condition, results of operations or cash flows in the future.

**New Senior Secured Credit Facilities**

On April 8, 2021, in connection with the completion of the G4S Acquisition, the Company entered into the
New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, consisting of the New First Lien USD Term Facility, the New First Lien Euro
Term Facility and the New Revolving Credit Facility with Credit Suisse AG, Cayman Islands Branch as administrative
agent and collateral agent and the lenders and financial institutions party thereto from time to time. The following is
a summary description of certain terms of the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities.

The New Senior Secured Credit Facilities are comprised of (i) the New First Lien USD Term Facility in an
aggregate principal amount of $950 million, (ii) the New First Lien Euro Term Facility in an aggregate principal
amount of €715.5 million and (iii) the New Revolving Credit Facility in an aggregate principal amount of
€300 million.

**Maturity; Mandatory Prepayments**

The New USD Term Facility and the New Euro Term Facility incurred under the New Senior Secured Credit
Facilities will mature on April 8, 2028. The New Revolving Credit Facility incurred under the New Senior Secured
Credit Facilities will mature on April 8, 2026.

Subject to certain exceptions, the New First Lien Term Loan Facilities will be subject to mandatory
prepayments, including in amounts equal to:

  - 100% of the net cash proceeds from issuances or the incurrence of debt by the Company or any of its
subsidiary guarantors (other than certain indebtedness permitted by the New First Lien Term Loan Facilities
and the New Revolving Credit Facility);

  - 100% of the net cash proceeds from certain sales or other dispositions of assets (including as a result of
casualty or condemnation) by the Company or any of the subsidiary guarantors in excess of a certain amount
and subject to customary reinvestment provisions and certain other exceptions; and

  - 50% (with stepdowns to 25% and 0% based upon achievement of specified first lien net leverage ratios) of
annual excess cash flow of the Company and its subsidiaries, subject to customary exceptions and limitations.

**Security; Guarantees**

The obligations of the Company under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities are guaranteed by certain of
our material wholly owned restricted subsidiaries, subject to customary exceptions and limitations (including agreed
security principles). The New Senior Secured Credit Facilities are also guaranteed by a parent of the Company.

The New First Lien Term Loan Facilities and the New Revolving Credit Facility are secured by a first priority
lien on the Term Priority Collateral and a second priority lien on the ABL Collateral (each as defined in the credit
agreement governing the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities), in each case, secured ratably on a pari passu basis
with the secured notes and related guarantees.


-----

**Interest**

The interest rate per annum applicable to loans issued under the New First Lien Term Loan Facility and the
New Revolving Credit Facility is based, at the Company’s election, on a fluctuating rate of interest determined by
reference to either (i) a base rate determined by reference to the higher of (a) the U.S. prime rate as quoted by The
Wall Street Journal, (b) the federal funds effective rate plus 0.5% and (c) (x) the London Interbank Offered Rate
(“LIBOR”) applicable for an interest period of one month, plus (y) 1.00% per annum, in each case, plus an applicable
margin or (ii) an adjusted LIBOR (or Euro Interbank Offered Rate (“EURIBOR”) based on currency) rate determined
by reference to the higher of (a) LIBOR (or EURIBOR) or SONIA (or as otherwise determined pursuant to the New
Senior Secured Credit Facilities) and (b) 0%, plus an applicable margin.

**Fees**

We will pay certain recurring fees with respect to the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and will continue to
do so, including, (i) fees on the unused commitments of the lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facility, (ii) letter
of credit fees on the aggregate face amounts of outstanding letters of credit plus a fronting fee to the issuing bank and
(iii) administration fees.

**Covenants**

The New Senior Secured Credit Facilities contain a number of customary affirmative and negative covenants
that, among other things, limit or restrict the ability of the Company and the guarantors to:

  - incur additional indebtedness (including guarantee obligations);

  - incur liens;

  - engage in mergers or other fundamental changes;

  - sell certain property or assets;

  - pay dividends or other distributions;

  - make acquisitions, investments, loans and advances;

  - prepay certain indebtedness;

  - change the nature of their business;

  - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; and

  - incur restrictions on contractual obligations limiting interactions between the Company and its subsidiaries
or limit actions in relation to the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities.

The New Revolving Credit Facility contains a springing financial covenant that requires the Company, solely
to the extent outstanding loans under the New Revolving Credit Facility on the last day of the Company’s fiscal quarter
exceed a certain threshold, to comply with a maximum first lien net leverage ratio of 7.75 to 1.00. Under the New
First Lien Term Loan Facilities and the New Revolving Credit Facility, consolidated EBITDA includes additional
add-backs to net income for certain costs, fees, taxes, losses, charges, write-offs, write-downs and expenses.

**Events of Default**

The New Senior Secured Credit Facilities contain customary events of default, including with respect to
nonpayment of principal, interest, fees or other amounts; material inaccuracy of a representation or warranty; failure


-----

to perform or observe covenants; bankruptcy and insolvency events; monetary judgment defaults; actual or asserted
invalidity or impairment of any material definitive loan documentation; and a change of control.

-----

The ABL Credit Facility is secured by a first priority lien over substantially all of the Company’s and each
guarantor’s cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, inventory and other current and related assets, subject to
certain exceptions (the “ABL Collateral”) and a second priority lien over substantially all of the Company’s and each
guarantor’s other assets, subject to certain exceptions (the “Term Priority Collateral”). The Existing First Lien Term
Loan Facility and the Existing Revolving Credit Facility are secured by a first priority lien on the Term Priority
Collateral and a second priority lien on the ABL Collateral, in each case, secured ratably on a pari passu basis with
the notes and related guarantees.

**Interest**

The interest rate per annum applicable to loans issued under the Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility and
the Existing Revolving Credit Facility is based, at the Company’s election, on a fluctuating rate of interest determined
by reference to either (i) a base rate determined by reference to the higher of (a) the U.S. prime rate as quoted by The
Wall Street Journal, (b) the federal funds effective rate plus 0.5% and (c) (x) the LIBOR applicable for an interest
period of one month, plus (y) 1.00% per annum, in each case, plus an applicable margin or (ii) an adjusted LIBOR
rate determined by reference to the higher of (a) LIBOR and (b) 0%, plus an applicable margin.

The interest rate per annum applicable to loans issued under the ABL Credit Facility is based on a fluctuating
rate of interest determined by reference to either (i) a base rate determined by reference to the higher of (a) the U.S.
prime rate as quoted by The Wall Street Journal, (b) the federal funds effective rate plus 0.5% and (c) (x) the LIBOR
rate applicable for an interest period of one month, plus (y) 1.00% per annum, in each case, plus an applicable margin
or (ii) an adjusted LIBOR rate determined by reference to the higher of (a) LIBOR and (b) 0%, in each case, plus an
applicable margin.

**Fees**

We pay certain recurring fees with respect to the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities and will continue
to do so, including, (i) fees on the unused commitments of the lenders under the ABL Credit Facility and the Existing
Revolving Credit Facility, (ii) letter of credit fees on the aggregate face amounts of outstanding letters of credit plus a
fronting fee to the issuing bank and (iii) administration fees.

**Covenants**

The Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities contain a number of customary affirmative and negative
covenants that, among other things, limit or restrict the ability of the Company and the guarantors to:

  - incur additional indebtedness (including guarantee obligations);

  - incur liens;

  - engage in mergers or other fundamental changes;

  - sell certain property or assets;

  - pay dividends or other distributions;

  - make acquisitions, investments, loans and advances;

  - prepay certain indebtedness;

  - change the nature of their business;

  - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; and

  - incur restrictions on contractual obligations limiting interactions between the Company and its subsidiaries
or limit actions in relation to the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities.


-----

The Existing Revolving Credit Facility contains a springing financial covenant that requires the Company,
solely to the extent outstanding loans under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility on the last day of the Company’s
fiscal quarter exceed a certain threshold, to comply with a maximum first lien net leverage ratio of 7.75 to 1.00. Under
the Existing First Lien Term Loan Facility and Existing Revolving Credit Facility, consolidated EBITDA includes
additional add-backs to net income for certain costs, fees, taxes, losses, charges, write-offs, write-downs and expenses.

In addition, the ABL Credit Facility contains a springing financial covenant that requires the Company, after
failure to meet the minimum availability threshold, to comply with a minimum fixed charge coverage ratio
(consolidated EBITDA less taxes and capital expenditures to Fixed Charges (as defined in the credit agreement
governing the ABL Credit Facility)) of 1.00 to 1.00. Under the ABL Credit Facility, consolidated EBITDA includes
additional add-backs to net income for certain costs, fees, taxes, losses, charges, write-offs, write-downs and expenses
and Fixed Charges include cash interest expenses and scheduled principal payments in respect of indebtedness.

**Events of Default**

The Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities contain customary events of default, including with respect to
nonpayment of principal, interest, fees or other amounts; material inaccuracy of a representation or warranty; failure
to perform or observe covenants; bankruptcy and insolvency events; monetary judgment defaults; actual or asserted
invalidity or impairment of any material definitive loan documentation; and a change of control.

**Redemption**

At any time prior to July 15, 2022, the Allied issuer and the Allied co-issuer may, at their option, redeem the

co-issuer experience certain change of control events, holders of the Existing 2026 Secured Notes may require the

**Existing G4S Debt**

**_G4S Notes_**

G4S International Finance plc (“G4S Finance”) has issued the following series of notes under its
£2,500,000,000 Euro Medium Term Note Programme (the “Programme”) which are guaranteed by G4S plc (G4S).
G4S Finance is a wholly-owned finance subsidiary of G4S.

  - On November 9, 2016, G4S Finance issued €500,000,000 1.50% Notes due 2023 (the “2023 Notes”) under
the Programme;

  - On June 2, 2017, G4S Finance issued €500,000,000 1.50% Notes due 2024 (the “2024 Notes”) under the
Programme; and

  - On May 24, 2018, G4S Finance issued €550,000,000 1.875% Notes due 2025 (the “2025 Notes,” and together
with the 2023 Notes and the 2024 Notes, the “G4S Notes”) under the Programme.

**Guarantees**

The payment of all sums expressed to be payable by G4S Finance in relation to the G4S Notes are
unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by G4S under a trust deed relating to the relevant G4S Notes (the “G4S
Trust Deed”). The obligations of G4S under the guarantees are direct, unconditional, unsubordinated and (subject to
the terms of the negative pledge as summarised below) unsecured obligations of G4S and (save for certain obligations
required to be preferred by law) rank equally with all other unsecured obligations (other than any subordinated
obligations) of G4S from time to time outstanding.


-----

**Ranking**

The G4S Notes constitute direct, unconditional, unsubordinated and (subject to subject to the terms of the
negative pledge as summarised below) unsecured obligations of G4S Finance and rank pari passu among themselves
and (save for certain obligations required to be preferred by law) equally with all other unsecured obligations (other
than any subordinated obligations) of G4S Finance from time to time outstanding.

**Interest; Maturity**

The 2023 Notes bear interest at a rate of 1.5% per annum (subject to the coupon step up/step down described
below). Interest on the 2023 Notes is payable annually in arrears on January 9 in each year. The 2023 Notes mature
on January 9, 2023, unless previously redeemed, purchased and/or cancelled.

The 2024 Notes bear interest at a rate of 1.5 % per annum (subject to the coupon step up/step down described
below). Interest on the 2024 Notes is payable annually in arrears on June 2 in each year. The 2024 Notes mature on
June 2, 2024, unless previously redeemed, purchased and/or cancelled.

The 2025 Notes bear interest at a rate of 1.875% per annum (subject to the coupon step up/step down
described below). Interest on the 2025 Notes is payable annually in arrears on May 24 in each year. The 2025 Notes
mature on May 24, 2025, unless previously redeemed, purchased and/or cancelled.

The terms and conditions of the G4S Notes contain a coupon step up/step down feature which is triggered if
the credit rating of G4S falls to below investment grade. From the interest payment date following the date of such
rating downgrade, a coupon step up margin of 1.25% per annum is payable on the G4S Notes. If the rating of G4S is
reinstated to investment grade, the coupon step up margin will no longer be payable from the following interest
payment date. The coupon step up margin is also payable if the G4S Notes are not assigned a rating for a period of 90
consecutive days.

**Negative Pledge**

The terms and conditions of the G4S Notes contain a customary capital markets negative pledge that limits
the ability of G4S Finance, G4S and their respective subsidiaries to create any security interest upon any present or
future business, undertaking, assets or revenues of G4S Finance, G4S and their respective subsidiaries to secure any
relevant indebtedness (defined as any indebtedness for notes or other securities which have a maturity of more than a
year and which are quoted, listed or ordinarily dealt in on any stock exchange or other securities market, and any
guarantee or indemnity in respect of any such indebtedness), unless (i) all amounts payable under the G4S Notes are
secured by the relevant security interest equally and rateably with the relevant indebtedness; or (ii) such other security
interest or other arrangement is provided as is approved by a resolution passed by holders of a majority of not less
than three quarters of the nominal amount of the G4S Notes (an “Extraordinary Resolution”).

**Events of Default**

The terms and conditions of the G4S Notes contain certain events of default (subject in certain cases to
customary grace and cure periods or certain other exceptions), which include, among others, non-payment of principal
or interest when due, failure to perform any obligations under the terms and conditions relating to the G4S Notes or
the trust deed relating to the G4S Notes, defaults in payment of certain other indebtedness for borrowed money, and
certain events of liquidation or insolvency. If an event of default occurs, the trustee relating to the G4S Notes may,
and if requested in writing by holders of at least one-fifth in nominal amount of the G4S Notes or if so directed by an
Extraordinary Resolution shall (subject to certain requirements), give notice to G4S and G4S Finance that the G4S
Notes shall become due and payable at their principal amount together with accrued interest as provided in the G4S
Trust Deed.


-----

**Redemption**

The terms and conditions of the G4S Notes provide certain early redemption options. The G4S Notes may
be redeemed at the option of G4S Finance on the occurrence of certain tax events. The G4S Notes also allow a put
right for holders upon the occurrence of a change of control put event. A change of control put event arises if (i) a
change of control occurs, (ii) the credit rating of the G4S Notes falls to below investment grade or the rating of the
G4S Notes is withdrawn as a result of the change of control, (iii) such ratings downgrade or withdrawal occurs before
the end of 120 days from the date of the change of control (such 120 period being subject to extension as further
described in the terms and conditions of the G4S Notes), and (iv) no reinstatement or replacement of the rating of the
G4S Notes to investment grade occurs during this period. The G4S Notes are redeemable at their principal amount
plus interest accrued to the date of redemption following early redemption for taxation reasons or a change of control
put.

G4S Finance, G4S and any of their respective subsidiaries may also purchase G4S Notes at any price in the
open market or otherwise. G4S Finance may at its option retain any G4A Notes which have been redeemed or
purchased for its own account and/or resell or cancel or otherwise deal with such G4S Notes at its discretion.

**_US Private Placement Senior Notes_**

**2019 Note Purchase Agreement**

On May 13, 2019, G4S Finance, as issuer, G4S, as parent guarantor, and the purchasers party thereto entered
into a note purchase and guaranty agreement (the “2019 Note Purchase Agreement”) related to the issuance by G4S
Finance of the following senior unsecured private placement notes:

  - $162,000,000 4.90% Series A Senior Unsecured Notes due May 13, 2026 (the “2019 Series A Notes”); and

  - $188,000,000 5.12% Series B Senior Unsecured Notes due May 13, 2029 (the “2019 Series B Notes” and,
together with the 2019 Series A Notes, the “2019 Private Placement Senior Notes”).

The proceeds from the sale of the 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes may be used to refinance existing
financial indebtedness and for general corporate purposes.

**Guarantees**

The obligations of G4S Finance under the 2019 Note Purchase Agreement and in respect of the 2019 Private
Placement Senior Notes are unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by G4S. The 2019 Note Purchase Agreement
also permits, and, if any subsidiary acts as a borrower, issuer or guarantor under any Principal Bank Facility (as defined
in the 2019 Note Purchase Agreement) or the 2007 Note Purchase Agreement requires, G4S Finance to obtain
guarantees from such subsidiaries of its obligations under and in respect of the 2019 Note Purchase Agreement and
the 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes. As of the date hereof, G4S Secure Solutions (USA) Inc. and G4S Holding
One, Inc. are subsidiary guarantors and have entered into subsidiary guarantee agreements with respect to such
subsidiary guarantees. The obligations of G4S and the subsidiary guarantors rank _pari passu_ in right of payment
without preference or priority, with all unsecured and unsubordinated financial indebtedness of such guarantor.

**Ranking**

The 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes rank pari passu among themselves and (save for certain obligations
required to be preferred by law) equally with all other unsecured obligations (other than any subordinated obligations)
of G4S Finance from time to time outstanding.


-----

**Interest; Maturity**

The 2019 Series A Notes bear interest at a rate of 4.90% per annum (subject to the coupon step up/step down
described below). Interest on the 2019 Series A Notes is payable semi-annually in arrear on May 13 and November
13 each year. The 2019 Series A Notes mature on May 13, 2026, unless previously redeemed, purchased and/or
cancelled.

The 2019 Series B Notes bear interest at a rate of 5.12% per annum (subject to the coupon step up/step down
described below). Interest on the 2019 Series B Notes is payable annually in arrear on May 13 and November 13 in
each year. The 2019 Series B Notes mature on May 13, 2029, unless previously redeemed, purchased and/or cancelled.

The 2019 Note Purchase Agreement contains a coupon step up/step down feature which is triggered (i) if the
long term senior debt credit rating of G4S by an approved rating agency falls below investment grade, such that (a)
there is one such rating and it is below investment grade, (b) there are two such ratings and one is below investment
grade, (c) there are three such ratings and at least two are below investment grade or (ii) if G4S ceases to have a long
term senior debt credit rating by an approved rating agency (each, a “Private Placement Notes Rating Event”). From
the interest payment date following the date of such Private Placement Notes Rating Event, a coupon step up margin
of 1.25% per annum is payable on the 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes. If the long term senior debt credit rating
of G4S is reinstated to investment grade by an approved rating agency, such that (a) there is only one such rating and
it is investment grade, (b) there are two such ratings and both are investment grade or (c) there are three such ratings
and any two are investment grade, the coupon step up margin will no longer be payable from the following interest
payment date.

**Covenants**

The 2019 Note Purchase Agreement contains a leverage covenant, which is measured as at the twelve-month
period ended on June 30 and 31 December each year (each, a “Relevant Period”). The leverage covenant requires that
G4S not permit the ratio of consolidated net indebtedness as of the last day of any Relevant Period to consolidated
EBITDA for such Relevant Period to exceed 3.5 to 1.0.

In addition, the 2019 Note Purchase Agreement also contains a number of customary covenants for private
placement notes that, among other things, limit or restrict the ability of G4S Finance, G4S and any subsidiary
guarantor, as applicable, subject to certain exceptions, to:

  - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness;

  - incur certain liens;

  - enter into transactions with affiliates;

  - merge or consolidate; and

  - transfer or sell assets.

**Events of Default**

The 2019 Note Purchase Agreement provides for events of default (subject in certain cases to customary
grace and cure periods), which include, among others, nonpayment of principal, interest or other premium when due,
breach of covenants or other agreements in the 2019 Note Purchase Agreement, defaults in payment of certain other
indebtedness and certain events of bankruptcy or insolvency. Generally, if event of default occurs, holders of more
than 50% of the aggregate principal amount of 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes (without regard to series)
outstanding (exclusive of notes then owned by G4S Finance, G4S or any of their respective affiliates) may declare all
principal, accrued and unpaid interest and make-whole amount in respect of the 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes
to be immediately due and payable; however, if a non-payment event of default occurs, any holder or holders of 2019


-----

Private Placement Senior Notes may declare all principal, accrued and unpaid interest and make-whole amount in
respect of such 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes held by it or them to be immediately due and payable.

**Redemption**

The terms and conditions of the 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes provide certain early redemption
options. The 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes may be redeemed at the option of G4S Finance, in an amount not
less than 5% of the aggregate principal amount of such 2019 Private Placement Notes then outstanding in case of a
partial prepayment, plus interest accrued to the date of redemption plus the make-whole amount, if any. The 2019
Note Purchase Agreement also requires G4S Finance to offer to prepay the entire unpaid principal amount of Notes
held by each holder at 100% of the principal amount of such notes at par, plus interest accrued to the prepayment date,
but without payment of the make-whole amount, upon the occurrence of a change of control. In addition, upon the
occurrence of certain asset dispositions, if G4S Finance elects to apply the net proceeds of such asset disposition to
repay or prepay outstanding unsubordinated indebtedness of G4S or any subsidiary of G4S, the 2019 Note Purchase
Agreement also requires G4S Finance to make an offer to each holder to prepay at par (without payment of the makewhole amount but with payment of interest accrued to the prepayment date) a pro rata portion of the 2019 Private
Placement Notes (without regard to series) held by such holder. The 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes also require
G4S Finance to make an offer to prepay at par (and without payment of the make-whole amount but with payment of
interest accrued to the prepayment date) the 2019 Private Placement Notes of affected holders upon the occurrence of
certain sanctions events. The 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes may also be redeemed at the option of G4S Finance
on the occurrence of certain tax events at 100% of the principal amount prepaid plus interest accrued to the prepayment
date plus the modified-make whole amount. G4S and G4S Finance are also permitted to make an offer to purchase
2019 Private Placement Senior Notes pro rata to the holders of all 2019 Private Placement Senior Notes at the time
outstanding upon the same terms and conditions (except to the extent necessary to reflect differences in the interest
rates and maturities of different series of notes).

**2007 Note Purchase Agreement**

On March 1, 2007, G4S, as issuer, and the purchasers party thereto entered into a note purchase agreement
(as amended by the first amendment to note purchase agreement dated May 13, 2019, the “2007 Note Purchase
Agreement”) related to the issuance by G4S of certain senior unsecured private placement notes (the “2007 Private
Placement Senior Notes”), of which the $105,000,000 6.06% Series D Senior Unsecured Notes due March 1, 2022
(the “2007 Series D Notes”) remain outstanding. The proceeds from the sale of the 2007 Private Placement Senior
Notes may be used to refinance existing financial indebtedness and for general corporate purposes.

**Guarantees**

The 2007 Note Purchase Agreement permits, and, if any subsidiary acts as a borrower, issuer or guarantor
under any Principal Bank Facility (as defined in the 2007 Note Purchase Agreement) or the 2019 Note Purchase
Agreement requires, G4S to obtain guarantees from such subsidiaries of its obligations under and in respect of the
2007 Note Purchase Agreement and the 2007 Private Placement Senior Notes. As of the date hereof, G4S Secure
Solutions (USA) Inc., G4S Holding One, Inc. and G4S Finance are subsidiary guarantors and have entered into
subsidiary guarantee agreements with respect to such subsidiary guarantees. The obligations of the subsidiary
guarantors rank pari passu in right of payment without preference or priority, with all unsecured and unsubordinated
financial indebtedness of such subsidiary guarantor.

**Ranking**

The 2007 Private Placement Senior Notes rank pari passu among themselves and (save for certain obligations
required to be preferred by law) equally with all other unsecured obligations (other than any subordinated obligations)
of G4S from time to time outstanding.


-----

**Interest; Maturity**

The 2007 Series D Notes bear interest at a rate of 6.06% per annum (subject to the coupon step up/step down
described below). Interest on the 2007 Series D Notes is payable semi-annually in arrear on March 1 and September
1 each year. The 2007 Series D Notes mature on March 1, 2022, unless previously redeemed, purchased and/or
cancelled.

The 2007 Note Purchase Agreement contains a coupon step up/step down feature which is triggered by the
occurrence of a Private Placement Notes Rating Event. From the interest payment date following the date of such
Private Placement Notes Rating Event, a coupon step up margin of 1.25% per annum is payable on the 2007 Private
Placement Senior Notes. If the long term senior debt credit rating of G4S is reinstated to investment grade by an
approved rating agency, such that (a) there is only one such rating and it is investment grade, (b) there are two such
ratings and both are investment grade or (c) there are three such ratings and any two are investment grade, the coupon
step up margin will no longer be payable from the following interest payment date.

**Covenants**

The 2007 Note Purchase Agreement contains a leverage covenant, which is measured as at the applicable
Relevant Period. The leverage covenant requires that G4S not permit the ratio of consolidated net indebtedness as of
the last day of any Relevant Period to consolidated EBITDA for such Relevant Period to exceed 3.5 to 1.0.

In addition, the 2007 Note Purchase Agreement also contains a number of customary covenants for private
placement notes that, among other things, limit or restrict the ability of G4S and any subsidiary guarantor, as
applicable, subject to certain exceptions, to:

  - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness;

  - incur certain liens;

  - enter into transactions with affiliates;

  - merge or consolidate; and

  - transfer or sell assets.

**Events of Default**

The 2007 Note Purchase Agreement provides for events of default (subject in certain cases to customary
grace and cure periods), which include, among others, nonpayment of principal, interest or other premium when due,
breach of covenants or other agreements in the 2007 Note Purchase Agreement, defaults in payment of certain other
indebtedness and certain events of bankruptcy or insolvency. Generally, if event of default occurs, holders of at least
51% of the aggregate principal amount of 2007 Private Placement Senior Notes outstanding (without regard to series
and exclusive of notes then owned by G4S or any of its affiliates) may declare all principal, accrued and unpaid interest
and make-whole amount in respect of the 2007 Private Placement Senior Notes to be immediately due and payable;
however, if a non-payment event of default occurs, any holder or holders of 2007 Private Placement Senior Notes may
declare all principal, accrued and unpaid interest and make-whole amount in respect of such 2007 Private Placement
Senior Notes held by it or them to be immediately due and payable.

**Redemption**

The terms and conditions of the 2007 Private Placement Senior Notes provide certain early redemption
options. The 2007 Private Placement Senior Notes may be redeemed at the option of G4S, in an amount not less than
5% of the aggregate principal amount of such 2019 Private Placement Notes then outstanding in case of a partial
prepayment, plus interest accrued to the date of redemption plus the make-whole amount, if any. The 2019 Private
Placement Senior Notes also require G4S Finance to offer to prepay the entire unpaid principal amount of Notes held


-----

by each holder at 100% of the principal amount of such notes at par, plus interest accrued to the prepayment date, but
without payment of the make-whole amount, upon the occurrence of a change of control. In addition, upon the
occurrence of certain asset dispositions, if G4S elects to apply the net proceeds of such asset disposition to repay or
prepay outstanding unsubordinated indebtedness of G4S or any subsidiary of G4S, the 2007 Note Purchase Agreement
also requires G4S to make an offer to each holder to prepay at par (and without payment of the make-whole amount
but with payment of interest accrued to the prepayment date) a pro rata portion of the 2007 Private Placement Notes
(without regard to series) held by such holder. The 2007 Private Placement Senior Notes may also be redeemed at the
option of G4S Finance on the occurrence of certain tax events at 100% of the principal amount prepaid plus interest
accrued to the prepayment date plus the modified-make whole amount. G4S is also permitted to make an offer to
purchase 2007 Private Placement Senior Notes pro rata to the holders of all 2007 Private Placement Senior Notes at
the time outstanding upon the same terms and conditions (except to the extent necessary to reflect differences in the
interest rates and maturities of different series of notes).

**_Issue of CP Notes under the CP Programme_**

In May 2020, G4S Finance issued £300,000,000 in aggregate principal amount of commercial paper (the “CP
Notes”). The CP Notes are guaranteed by G4S and are scheduled to mature on May 14, 2021.

The CP Notes were issued under G4S and G4S Finance’s euro-commercial paper programme (the “CP
Programme”). The CP Programme was established in May 2020 in order to borrow under the Bank of England’s
Covid Corporate Financing Facility (the “CCFF”).

**Guarantee**

The payment of all sums expressed to be payable by G4S Finance in relation to the CP Notes are
unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by G4S pursuant to a deed of guarantee entered into in connection with
the CP Programme. The obligations of G4S under the guarantee are direct, unconditional and unsecured obligations
of G4S and rank and will rank at least pari passu with all present and future unsecured and unsubordinated obligations
of G4S other than obligations mandatorily preferred by law applying to companies generally.

**Ranking**

The G4S Notes constitute a direct and unsecured obligation of G4S Finance ranking at least pari passu with
all present and future unsecured and unsubordinated obligations of G4S Finance other than obligations mandatorily
preferred by law applying to companies generally.

**Interest; Maturity**

The CP Notes were issued at a discount and do not bear interest. The CP Notes mature on May 14, 2021,
unless previously redeemed.

**Negative Pledge**

The CP Notes do not contain a negative pledge.

**Events of Default**

The CP Notes do not contain any events of default.

**Redemption**

Pursuant to the rules of the CCFF, G4S Finance may request the early redemption of the CP Notes. The
acceptance of any such early redemption request by G4S Finance is at the discretion of the Bank of England and HM
Treasury.

By virtue of these limitations, a Guarantor’s obligation under its Secured Note Guarantee could be
significantly less than amounts payable with respect to the Secured Notes, or a Guarantor may have effectively no

the Notes—Federal and state fraudulent conveyance or fraudulent transfer laws permit a court, under certain

circumstances, to avoid the notes offered hereby and the guarantees, and the liens securing the secured notes offered

The Secured Note Guarantee of a Guarantor will be automatically and unconditionally released and

shall also be reinstated to the extent that such Guarantor would then be required to provide a Secured

Limitation on guarantees of Indebtedness by Restricted Subsidiaries”;

(6) upon the merger, amalgamation or consolidation of any Guarantor with and into the Issuer, the CoIssuers or another Guarantor or upon the liquidation of such Guarantor, in each case, in compliance with
the applicable provisions of the Secured Indenture;

Note Guarantee shall be reinstated upon the Reversion Date; and

(8) as described under the caption “—Amendment, Supplement and Waiver.”

Notwithstanding the foregoing, any Secured Note Guarantee by a Parent Entity may be automatically and

**Ranking**

The payment of the principal of, premium, if any, and interest on the Secured Notes and the payment of any
Secured Note Guarantee will rank pari passu in right of payment to all existing and future Senior Indebtedness of
the Issuer, the Co-Issuers or the relevant Guarantor, as the case may be, including the obligations of the Issuer, the
Co-Issuers and such Guarantor under the Senior Credit Facilities, the Existing 2026 Secured Notes, the Existing
2027 Unsecured Notes and the Unsecured Notes.

The Secured Notes and the Secured Note Guarantees will be effectively senior in right of payment to all of the
Issuer’s, the Co-Issuers’ and any Guarantor’s existing and future unsecured Indebtedness to the extent of the value
of the assets securing the Secured Notes. As of December 31, 2020, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the
Transactions, the Issuers and the Guarantors would have had Secured Indebtedness of approximately
$9,120.0 million outstanding (excluding capitalized leases), including borrowings and the related guarantees under
the Senior Credit Facilities, the Existing 2026 Secured Notes and the Secured Notes with $300.0 million and €300.0
million available for borrowing under the revolving credit facilities under the Credit Agreements and
$1,500.0 million available for borrowing under the ABL Credit Facility, without giving effect to approximately
$275.0 million of outstanding letters of credit at December 31, 2020, which, if drawn, would be Secured
Indebtedness.

Although the Secured Indenture will contain limitations on the amount of additional Indebtedness that the
Issuer and its Restricted Subsidiaries may incur the amount of such additional Indebtedness could be substantial and,
in any case, such Indebtedness may be Secured Indebtedness or Senior Indebtedness. See “—Certain Covenants—
Limitation on Incurrence of Indebtedness and Issuance of Disqualified Stock and Preferred Stock.”

**Paying Agent and Registrar for the Secured Notes**

The Issuers will maintain one or more Paying Agents for the Secured Notes. The initial Paying Agent for the
USD Secured Notes Tranche 1 and the USD Secured Notes Tranche 2 will be the Trustee, and the initial Paying
Agent for the Euro Secured Notes and the Sterling Secured Notes will be The Bank of New York Mellon Trust
Company, N.A. The Issuers will also maintain one or more registrars and a transfer agent. The initial registrar and
transfer agent with respect to the USD Secured Notes Tranche 1 and the USD Secured Notes Tranche 2 will be the
Trustee, and the initial registrar and transfer agent with respect to the Euro Secured Notes and the Sterling Secured
Notes will be The Bank of New York Mellon Trust Company, N.A. The applicable registrar will maintain a register
reflecting ownership of the Secured Notes outstanding from time to time. The registered Holder will be treated as
the owner of a Secured Note for all purposes. Only registered Holders will have rights under the Secured Indenture.
The applicable Paying Agent will make payments on the Secured Notes, and the applicable transfer agent will
facilitate transfer of Secured Notes on behalf of the Issuers. Payments of principal of, premium and Additional
Amounts, if any, and interest on the Secured Notes will be payable at the office or agency designated by the Issuers
or, at the option of the Issuers, payment of interest may be made by check mailed to the Holders at their respective
addresses set forth in the register of Holders. Until otherwise designated by the Issuers, the Issuers’ office or agency
maintained for such purpose will be the office of the applicable Paying Agent.

The Issuers may change the Paying Agents, the registrars or the transfer agents without prior notice to the
Holders. The Issuer or any of its Subsidiaries may act as a Paying Agent, registrar or transfer agent. However, for so
long as any series of Secured Notes is listed on the Exchange and if and to the extent that the rules of the Authority
so require, the Issuers will notify the Authority of any change of Paying Agent, registrar or transfer agent.

**Transfer and Exchange**

A Holder may transfer or exchange Secured Notes in accordance with the terms of the Secured Indenture and
the restrictions set forth in the section of this Offering Circular entitled “Transfer Restrictions.” The applicable
registrar, the applicable Paying Agent and the Trustee may require a Holder to furnish appropriate endorsements and
transfer documents in connection with a transfer of Secured Notes. Holders will be required to pay all Taxes due on
transfer. The Issuers will not be required to transfer or exchange any Secured Note selected for redemption or


-----

tendered (and not withdrawn) for repurchase in connection with a Change of Control Offer, an Asset Sale Offer or
other tender offer. Also, the Issuers will not be required to issue, register the transfer of or exchange any Secured
Note during the period of 15 days before the delivery of a notice of redemption of Secured Notes or between a
record date and the next succeeding interest payment date.

**Security**

The Secured Notes, Secured Note Guarantees and the other Secured Notes Obligations will have the benefit of
the “Collateral,” which will consist of (i) the Notes Collateral, as to which the Holders of the Secured Notes, holders
of the Credit Agreement Obligations, holders of the Existing 2026 Secured Notes and future Other Pari Passu Lien
Obligations (if any) will have a first-priority security interest (subject to Permitted Liens) and the ABL Lenders and
the other holders of ABL Obligations will have a second-priority security interest, and (ii) the ABL Collateral, as to
which the ABL Lenders and the other holders of ABL Obligations will have a first-priority security interest and the
Holders of the Secured Notes, holders of the Credit Agreement Obligations, holders of the Existing 2026 Secured
Notes and future Other Pari Passu Lien Obligations (if any) will have a second-priority security interest (subject to


-----

Permitted Liens). The Collateral granted by or over the assets of or equity interests in any Foreign Subsidiary will be
subject to the Agreed Security Principles.

**_Notes Collateral_**

The Notes Collateral will be pledged as collateral to the Notes Collateral Agent for the benefit of the Trustee,
the Notes Collateral Agent, the other Agents and the Holders of the Secured Notes. The Notes Collateral will also be
pledged as collateral to the Credit Agreement Collateral Agent for the benefit of the Credit Agreement Obligations.
The Secured Notes and Secured Note Guarantees, together with the Credit Agreement Obligations, the Existing
2026 Secured Notes and future Other Pari Passu Lien Obligations (if any), will be secured by first-priority security
interests in the Notes Collateral, subject to Permitted Liens. The Notes Collateral generally consists of substantially
all present and future tangible and intangible assets of the Issuers and the Guarantors (including, all of the Capital
Stock owned by the Issuers or any Guarantor other than Excluded Equity Interests) and in each case other than
(i) the ABL Collateral and (ii) Excluded Assets.

Initially, subject to Permitted Liens, only the Secured Notes, the Secured Note Guarantees, the other Secured
Notes Obligations, the Existing 2026 Secured Notes and the Credit Agreement Obligations will have the benefit of
the first-priority security interest in the Notes Collateral. Except for Indebtedness secured by Permitted Liens
(including the Credit Agreement Obligations and, subject to the terms described herein, future Indebtedness
constituting Other Pari Passu Lien Obligations), no other Indebtedness incurred by the Issuers or any Guarantor may
share in the first-priority security interest in the Notes Collateral.

The Issuers and the Guarantors will grant a second-priority Lien on and security interest in the Notes
Collateral for the benefit of the ABL Lenders and the other holders of ABL Obligations, which initially will consist
of the loans outstanding under the ABL made by the ABL Lenders, obligations with respect to letters of credit
issued under the ABL, certain hedging obligations incurred pursuant to a Secured Hedge Agreement and Banking
Product Obligations and any other ABL Obligations under the ABL. Any additional Indebtedness that is incurred by
the Issuers or any Guarantor in compliance with the terms of the Secured Indenture may also be given a Lien on and
security interest in the Notes Collateral that ranks pari passu or junior to the Lien of the Noteholder Secured Parties
in the Notes Collateral. See “—Certain Covenants—Liens.” Except as provided in the ABL Intercreditor
Agreement, holders of junior Liens on the Notes Collateral will not be able to take any enforcement action with
respect to the Notes Collateral so long as any Secured Notes are outstanding.

**_ABL Collateral_**

The ABL Collateral will be pledged as collateral to the Notes Collateral Agent for the benefit of the Trustee,
the Notes Collateral Agent, the other Agents and the Holders of the Secured Notes. The ABL Collateral will also be
pledged as collateral to the Credit Agreement Collateral Agent for the benefit of the Credit Agreement Obligations.
The Secured Notes and the Secured Note Guarantees, together with the other Secured Notes Obligations, the Credit
Agreement Obligations, the Existing 2026 Secured Notes and future Other Pari Passu Lien Obligations (if any), will
be secured by second-priority security interests in the ABL Collateral, subject to Permitted Liens. The ABL
Collateral generally consists of the following assets of the Issuers and the Guarantors (other than Excluded Assets)
whether now owned or hereafter acquired:

     - accounts (including credit card receivables) and all other rights to payment arising from services

rendered or from the sale, lease, use or other disposition of inventory, whether such rights to payment
constitute payment intangibles, letter-of-credit rights or any other classification of property, or are
evidenced in whole or in part by instruments, chattel paper or documents;

     - inventory and documents relating to inventory;

     - all rights of an unpaid vendor with respect to inventory;

     - deposit accounts (other than accounts constituting Excluded Assets separately maintained insurance

deposit accounts and deposit accounts maintained solely to hold proceeds of Notes Collateral (a
“Collateral Account”)), commodity accounts, securities accounts and lockboxes, including all money
and certificated securities, uncertificated securities (other than Capital Stock of Subsidiaries of the
Issuers and the Guarantors), securities entitlements and related investment property (including all cash,


-----

marketable securities and other funds held in or on deposit in any deposit account, commodity account
or securities account), and all cash and cash equivalents, including cash and cash equivalents securing
reimbursement obligations in respect of letters of credit or other ABL Obligations;

     - instruments, chattel paper and general intangibles pertaining to the other items of property otherwise

comprising ABL Collateral (other than any Capital Stock of Subsidiaries of the Issuers and Guarantors
and intellectual property);

     - books and records, supporting obligations, documents and related letters of credit, letter-of-credit rights,

commercial tort claims or other claims and causes of action, in each case, to the extent arising out of,
related to or given in exchange or settlement of any of the foregoing; and

     - all substitutions, replacements, accessions, products and proceeds (including, without limitation,

insurance proceeds, licenses, royalties, income, payments, claims, damages and proceeds of suit) of all
or any of the foregoing.

All terms used in the preceding paragraph and defined in the UCC and not otherwise defined in this offering
circular have the meanings given to such terms in the UCC; provided that the term “instrument” has the meaning
given to such term in Article 9 of the UCC.

Notwithstanding the foregoing, but subject to the provisions of the ABL Intercreditor Agreement, the ABL
Collateral will not include any identifiable cash proceeds from a sale, lease, conveyance or other disposition of any
Notes Collateral that has been deposited in the Collateral Account in accordance with the terms of the Secured
Indenture, the Collateral Documents and the ABL Intercreditor Agreement, until such time as such cash proceeds
are released therefrom in accordance with the terms of such agreements.

**_Limitation on Certain Collateral and Perfection Items_**

The Issuers and their Subsidiaries will not be required under the terms of the Secured Indenture or the
Collateral Documents to deliver landlord lien waivers, estoppels or collateral access letters and will not be required
to subject any accounts (other than any Collateral Account), securities accounts or commodities accounts to control
agreements; provided that Collateral shall not include any Excluded Assets or Excluded Equity Interests. Any
Collateral granted by or over the assets of or equity interests in a Foreign Subsidiary will be subject to the Agreed
Security Principles.

**_Possession of the Collateral_**

Subject to the terms of the Collateral Documents, and unless an Event of Default shall have occurred and be
continuing and the Notes Collateral Agent or, subject to the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreements, the ABL
Collateral Agent, Credit Agreement Collateral Agent or Existing 2026 Secured Notes Collateral Agent shall have
commenced enforcement of remedies with respect to the Collateral, the Issuers and the Guarantors will have the
right to remain in possession and retain exclusive control of the Collateral securing the Obligations under the
Secured Notes, the Secured Note Guarantees and the Secured Indenture (other than any cash, securities and Cash
Equivalents constituting part of the Collateral and deposited with the Notes Collateral Agent or the ABL Collateral
Agent, as applicable in accordance with the provisions of the Collateral Documents), to freely operate the Notes
Collateral and to collect, invest and dispose of any income therefrom. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our
Indebtedness and the Notes—Sales of assets by the issuers and the guarantors could reduce the collateral and the
related guarantees.” Any Collateral granted by or over the assets of or equity interests in a Foreign Subsidiary will
be subject to the Agreed Security Principles.

**_Information Regarding Collateral_**

The Issuers will furnish to the Notes Collateral Agent, with respect to the Issuers or any Guarantor (other than
where such Person is a non-U.S. Issuer or Guarantor), prompt written notice of any change in such Person’s
(i) organizational name, (ii) jurisdiction of organization or formation, (iii) identity or organizational structure or
(iv) organizational identification number. The Issuers and the Guarantors will agree to make all filings under the
UCC or equivalent statutes, or otherwise that are required by applicable law in order for the Notes Collateral Agent


-----

to continue at all times following such change to have a valid, legal and perfected security interest in all the
Collateral.

**_Further Assurances and After-Acquired Property_**

Subject to the applicable limitations set forth in the Collateral Documents and subject to the Agreed Security
Principles and the Secured Indenture (including with respect to Excluded Assets), the Issuers and the Guarantors
shall execute any and all further documents, financing statements, applications for registration, agreements and
instruments, and take all further action that may be required under applicable law, or that the Notes Collateral Agent
may reasonably request, in order to grant, preserve, protect and perfect the validity and priority of the security
interests created or intended to be created by the Collateral Documents in the Collateral. Subject to the applicable
limitations set forth in the Collateral Documents and the Secured Indenture (including with respect to Excluded

perfected security interest (subject to the Agreed Security Principles) under the Collateral Documents and such

as required by the Secured Indenture and the Collateral Documents and take all actions required by the Collateral
Documents and the Secured Indenture to perfect the liens created by the Collateral Documents.

Notwithstanding the foregoing, until the Discharge of the ABL Obligations, the Issuers and the Guarantors
shall only be required to comply with the foregoing requirements with respect to any ABL Collateral to the extent
that such ABL Collateral is concurrently being pledged to secure the ABL Obligations.

**_Collateral Documents and Certain Related Intercreditor Provisions_**

Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Issuers, the Guarantors and the Notes Collateral Agent (on
behalf of the Trustee and the Holders of the Secured Notes) will enter into one or more Collateral Documents
creating and establishing the terms of the security interests that secure the Secured Notes and the Secured Note
Guarantees. These security interests will secure the payment and performance when due of all of the obligations of
the Issuers and the Guarantors under the Secured Notes, the Secured Indenture, the Secured Note Guarantees and the
Collateral Documents, as provided in the Collateral Documents. The Issuers and the Guarantors will complete all
filings and other similar actions required by the Collateral Documents in connection with the provision and/or
perfection of security interests in the Collateral that may be perfected by the filing of a financing statement under the
UCC and the pledge of the Capital Stock of any Domestic Subsidiary (to the extent not constituting an Excluded
Asset), in each case on the Issue Date. In addition, the Issuers and the Guarantors shall use their commercially
reasonable efforts to complete all other filings and other similar actions required by the Collateral Documents in
connection with the provision and/or perfection of security interests on other Collateral on the Issue Date, but to the
extent they are unable to do so without undue burden or expense, will in any event complete such actions promptly
following the Issue Date. Wilmington Trust, National Association will be appointed, pursuant to the Secured
Indenture, as the Notes Collateral Agent. The Trustee, the Notes Collateral Agent, the other Agents and each Holder
of Secured Notes and each other holder of, or obligee in respect of, any Obligations in respect of the Secured Notes
outstanding at such time are referred to collectively as the “Noteholder Secured Parties.”

With regard to any property upon which a security interest must be perfected, pursuant to the Collateral
Documents and the Agreed Security Principles such security interests and Liens will be created under the Collateral
Documents in form and substance reasonably necessary to grant to the Notes Collateral Agent, on behalf of the
Holders of the Secured Notes, a security interest in such collateral and the Issuers and the Guarantors shall deliver or
cause to be delivered to the Notes Collateral Agent, on behalf of the Holders of the Secured Notes, all such
instruments and documents (including certificates, legal opinions and lien searches) as are necessary to evidence
compliance with this covenant and required by the Collateral Documents.
